content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												Extremely fun game, ruined by its community. Let me explain: The fun in this game is learning, and growing your characters and items in level. The fun isn't in BEING level 100 with level 100 gear. The fun is in PROGRESSIVELY GETTING THERE. But the community is all about boosting, which can give you 30+ levels in an hour, and gifting high level (sometimes hacked) items. So instead of experiencing the joy of progressively getting there, increasing this and that, instead you are suddenly propelled to new heights. And while that boost seems great at the very moment it happened, this pleasure is infinitely short-lived.This is the reason I created my group, Dungeon Defenders Hardcore, for players that care about having fun with the game, not just reaching level 100 ASAP. What then? You know?Other than that, this is an awesome game, and I am looking forward to Dungeon Defenders 2.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2012
												I recommend this game on one condition: that you do not play it past completing Insane difficulty. I know my playtime suggest a lot of hours and a lot of fun but the ramp up in difficulty has left a bad taste in my mouth knowing I won't be able to experience the full game unless I grind endlessly. It becomes less of a game about having fun with tower defense and more about min-maxing stats while simultaneously avoiding cheaters who mess up your characters and possessive teammates who think they have the "optimal placement" and will sell your towers with wild abandon. It was such a fun game while I played but after a certain point things just got worse and I stopped having fun. I'm just sort of bitter at the end of it all.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												So after 500 hours in this game and reaching end game items I feel like I can write a objective and well-informed review about the game.Overall, I don't recommend it.However, if you want to play with friends, say you buy a 4-pack (on sale, of course) and you stay off the dlc's, it is a nice purchase. Playing the game all the way up to lvl 70 pre-nightmare mode, the game is lots of fun and very unique. It is after that point where it just isn't worth it.The person in charge of development got really greedy with the game and started releasing lots of dlc's, each one containing either one hero or one map. Which means you have to spend a lot of money to get the full experience of the late game.On top of that, nightmare mode is such a cliff that you are pretty much forced to buy the summoner and EV dlcs in order to progress through it, as well as farm for hours in order to get decent items. The big flaw in the game is that it relies on RGN; the items rely on stats that are randomly generated. And instead of fixing this system, the devs decided to just give you more items so hopefully you eventually get a lucky drop. Most of the items generated are either missing key stats, or have negative values on them thus reducing your chances of getting anything decent.The trading community is slowly dying if not dead, since most good players decided to move onto better games.So like I said, I enjoyed the first few hours pre nightmare, but after that it just isn't worth your time or money.PS. Has your family or a good friend ever drag you to do something you do not wanna do but you do it anyway out of the goodness of your heart? yeah... that's why I played 500 hours of this game

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												Dungeon Defenders it's not regular tower-defense game , it's TD with a third-person action+rpg, and it’s looking amazing. The game is filled with all sorts of entertainment, really all sorts. DD has not only classic maps, when you try protect your crystal from hordes of enemies but also various types of challenge, such as offensive defense, defense without towers, hunting turkeys, even challenge assist Cupid in love affairs and many others.- Game have very colorful graphics. Let everyone decide for themselves if this good or bad.- Game has a ton of weapons and armor with randomly generated characteristics.-In standard game only 4 classes, but with DLC number of heroes rise to 12- Each class has a unique traps or towers or another defense units.- DD have 5 levels of difficulty, and hardcore mode for true players- In the game you have the haven -  tavern, where you store all your cups, which represent your accomplishments- New equipment can received not only from  dropped by killing monsters, or collected as rewards after defeating waves of enemies, also you can visit in-game shops, and buy there new equipment.  Everyone players can create in-game shop.- All equipment have level and player can can raise this level by investing in equipment lot of mana.The storyline is missing in the game, although there are a couple of movies. But all this is secondary. Almost all pastime in the game, we will killing monsters! We will be happy to kill them again and again, and we will receive level ups one by one, we will improve our weapons again and again. Everywhere will be a river of blood and body of orcs, that sunk into oblivion , we will step over them and kill new hordes , trying to get the coveted award.Game highly recommended for all fans of TD!!!Rating 9 from 9,5Sorry for my English!------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Dungeon Defenders это не обычная Tower Defense - это экшен+рпг TD с видом от третьего лица и у разработчиков вышло просто отличное сочетание жанров. Игра наполнена всяческого рода развлечениями, на самом деле всех видов. ДД имеет не только классические карты, когда вы пытаетесь защитить ваш кристалл от полчищ врагов , но и различные типы испытаний , такие как уничтожение вражеских кристаллов , обора своего кристалла без башен , охота на индеек , даже испытание помощи Амуру в любовных делах ,когда вы будете выступать в роли его помощника сводя между собой пары одиноких орков.- В игре очень красочная и вычурная графика. Пусть каждый решает для себя хорошо или плохо.- Игра имеет тонны оружия и брони, стыты у которых рендомно генерируются.- В стандартной игре всего 4 классы, но с DLC количество героев вырастет до 12- Каждый класс обладает уникальными способами уничтожения врагов: ловушки, защитные и атакующие сооружения, призыв монстров.- В ДД есть 5 уровней сложности и хардкор режим для тру- игроков- В игре у вас есть убежище - таверна , где хранятся все ваши кубки , которые олицетворяют ваши достижения- Новый шмот может получить не только от убийства монстров , или награды за успешное прохождение карты , также вы можете посетить в игре магазины , и купить там новое оружие и броню . Каждый игрок может создать в игре магазины и продавать все что пожелает, ну почти все..- Вся экипировка имеет уровень и игрок может может поднять этот уровень , инвестируя в оборудование много манны, очень много.Сюжетной линии как таковой в игре и нет. Но все это вторично. Почти все времяпрепровождение в игре, мы будем проводить убивая монстров ! Мы будем получать дикий фан делая это. Получая уровень за уровнем, апгрейдя оружие, мы будем убивать зеленых и не только орков всевозможными способами. Повсюду будут реки крови, ну или кристаллов, так как крови в игре и нет. Мы будем идти вперед переступая, через тела канувших в лету врагов, стремясь заполучить желанную награду. !Игра рекомендуется для всех поклонников TD !Моя оценка 9,5 из 10!! Мой обзор Dungeon Defenders Eternity

number of helpful: 372 of 612 people (61%) found this review helpful105 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												No, I would not recommend this game to anyone, for any reason. At the tail end of of almost a thousand hours, and after careful deliberation, I cannot find anything redeeming in Dungeon Defenders. Not its single-player, not it's multi-player, certainly not its Tower Defense, not its loot mechanics, and, most assuredly, not its community. The whole Dungeon Defenders experience, from the first achievement for simply following a tutorial, to the last achievement in killing four giant snowmen and an alcoholic Santa Claus, is garbage. Let me get this out of the way – The original thirteen maps of Dungeon Defenders and the original four classes, they're fine. The original, vanilla Dungeon Defenders experience, although simplistic, has a very clear and defined progression. Your four classes – the Apprentice, the Squire, the Huntress, and the Monk – are fairly well balanced for both solo play and multiplayer, and because you can swap characters during maps in solo play, you can make doubly strong defense setups with combinations from those four classes. It is entirely possible, with good tower strategies, to go from the beginning of the game to the end of the game – that is, from Deeper Well to Glitterhelm Caverns - all on the same difficulty with hardly any farming, up to the tail end of Insane difficulty. The original Dungeon Defenders, simplistic it may be, is roughly fifty hours of a tight tower defense experience with a lot of experimentation possible within it.Enter Nightmare. Enter spiders, enter djinns, and enter sharkens. Which, alright, those aren't bad. These are enemies that are designed to target and disrupt your defenses so that you'd have to reconsider your defense setups. Up to Insane, you weren't really punished for not using all four classes, so Nightmare is the point where the game decides to kick you around a bit and force you to play it better. So, you'll go back and level up a new class to use in conjunction with your usual class and take another crack at it.So with a format like this, how did this game get screwed so badly?DLC upon DLC happened, ramping the game's difficulty by numbers up faster than players could keep up with it. You could gotten away with playing with lower stats if it weren't for the Sky City patch that introduced Goblin Copters. Goblin Copters dropping their buffed up Ogres on your defenses alone increased the minimum stat requirements for maps by quite a bit. After that, maps began spamming Ogres ad nauseum just as a difficulty supplement rather than having actual difficulty within the map's designs. Suddenly, people couldn't keep up with the game's difficulty without farming late waves of Survival mode for incrementally better gear. But the random number generator was bugged, so it wasn't giving out progressively stronger gear as often as it should have been. And so, people spent more time farming in the game than they do actually progressing in it. Entire class DLCs – The Series EV, the Jester, and the Summoner – were released just to keep the game possible to beat, rather than to supplement the game with new and interesting ways to play it. By the real end of the game, those classes are a requirement to succeed. If you favored the Squire or the Apprentice when you began playing the game, they are going to gather dust in your character roster because the real end of the game doesn't even have actual tower defense in the way that the very first thirteen maps do.Let's also keep in mind that most of the DLC is outsourced to the winners of map contests held by Trendy on their official Dungeon Defenders forums (that unnavigable mess) and other DLCs are very clearly sourced to a different set of developers from the initial game. What this means is that there's a ton of maps in the game that have an inconsistent graphical quality and difficulty – difficulty, by the way, at this point rarely amounts to anything more than using the same three correct classes over and over in the correct spots with no room for experimentation. Then, those maps take anywhere from twenty to forty minutes at a time because of rapidly inflating mob counts per wave.Look, I get that a difficulty name like “Nightmare” means, okay, the game is going to be hard now, and that naturally does mean you're going to need higher stats to beat older maps, as well as be pretty damn tough in order to meet the requirements of the endgame. That's standard difficulty in game design. And Dungeon Defenders does that! Initially, Nightmare mode challenges your perception of building maps to compensate for spiders dropping in behind your defenses, sharkens who can charge in and completely push them out of the way, and djinns who can just outright destroy them. But, the metagame changed. Suddenly, the solution is always a line of summons on a buff beam underneath a stack of auras. Every special mob and the threat presents is handled by that solution alone. And with that one-size fits all solution, it becomes the only solution that maps are designed around. Difficulty is reduced to a stat requirement on a board that says, “Here. This is how difficult it is, this is what kind of numbers you need to scrape by on the skin of your teeth with, this is what kind of numbers you need to beat it comfortably and farm it, and this is what kind of super low number you can beat it with to stroke your ePeen. These are the points you need to put on the DLC Summoner, the DLC Series EV, the Monk, and the Huntress. Haha, what? Apprentice and Squire? Those aren't relevant.” And that says nothing of building a character for tackling bosses.Once you get somewhere new in Dungeon Defenders, get comfortable. You're gonna be there for a while, until you get lucky. By a Trendy developer's own admission, the stats on drops are bugged so that they rollover – become worse than they should be when they're spawned – and thus the progression is more restrictive than it was ever intended to be. And indeed, DLC was released to try and get around that too. But DLC can't fix a fundamentally broken game, and in fact, it actually broke it more, because the loot coming out of it was too god, so it came out gimped, per that bug. It is actually to the point where, in order to maximize your chances of getting loot that will give you better stats, and thus, help you move forward, an X-Box controller emulator was devised in order to take advantage of splitscreen. This is so you can have four chances at a map's rewards, rather than just the one, for your thirty minute run of what-the-hell-ever map. And I expect that this tool was only ever intended for the obsessive munchkin crowd, but it rapidly turned into a requirement to proceed at all in the game. This is not tower defense. This is just farming and reaping the rewards of poor soil.So, now that you understand what a majority of Dungeon Defenders is, I want you to take a look at the Most Helpful (All Time) reviews here on Steam for this game. Most of them are from people with people whose hours number in the multiple thousands. I hope that at least explaining the arbitrary farming puts into context those hours. Dungeon Defenders, even with all its DLC, does not have nearly enough content to justify those lengths of time, or, hell, even my own, and by its own design, it's not a game I could recommend to anyone.It's a bad game.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2016
Summary/Overview  Dungeon Defenders is a fps, tower defense, strategy and RPG game developed by the nice people over at Trendy Entertainment. The only series they are currently known for is Dungeon Defenders with only two games so far, Dungeon Defenders and Dungeon Defenders II. Dungeon Defenders four starting heroes are  the Squire, Monk, Huntress and Apprentice in which you are called upon to save your parents, adult versions of yourself from the land of Etheria. The last map is called Crystalline Dimension which is the only map in the whole entire game in which you will encounter your parents that have been kidnapped frozen into a crystalline substance. You face an enemy, a final boss known as the Old one which is a term that is symbolic of a satanic type demon. Your main goal in the whole game is to survive wave after wave with hordes of enemies such as sharken, djinn, goblins, trolls, ogres, wyverns, spiders and others as you have thousands of enemies usually per wave. The end goal is to survive all waves and make it to a final boss on each map on the campaign mode. It has a story, xp leveling system, loot, pets, items, weapons and accessories characteristic of most role-playing games. Features  Trading System/ Farming Community/ Trading Forums      If you have been playing computer games for a long while and have never heard of farming, let me now educate you on it and my personal pet peeve and vendetta with it. Farming is an action in role-playing games that are composed of loot and is needed in the progressing of the game in order to improve damage and defense output against enemies and large bosses. Farming is a systematic process and cycle that habitually reoccurs whereby players grind to get a variety of weapons, armor, pets and accessories with different tiers, rarities and qualities. So, farming by itself seems like a rather harmless endeavor that was originally meant for the progression of games in which a random number generator selects random stats, some good, some missing in key areas and some with all important stats that use specific algorithms towards item production which is then consumed by users for their own personal gain within the game and can even be sold on trading forums.  The Misconceptions of the Farming Agglomerated Half of the Community     Hackers have been present in Dungeon Defenders since the first three months of its PC release in late 2011 right before the Christmas holiday. Item checkers were called upon to volunteer their time given special privileges and spreadsheets in order to validate the authenticity of all stats on weapons, pets, duped event items without a trace, and duped weapons, pets and armor that lie outside of the minimum and maximum values they are given to work with that are spawnable in the actual game. The random number generated catastrophe led others at the time in 2013 towards a new downloadable content map called Lab Assault that soon came out. Trendy's only motivation for releasing this map was to generate more numbers in the community since many people were leaving their game and numbers of people playing in the community finally reached an all-time low before summer 2013. In order to avoid this, they instituted what is now one of the largest farming endeavor maps into more modern gaming. Lab assault is a tedious and laborious map that last anywhere from three to four minutes per run meant to provide users with a very quick shortcut towards obtaining the highest armor in the game. Armor ranges in the following order of rarity: godly, mythical, transcendent, ultimate, ultimate plus and ultimate plus-plus. In order to use transcendent items, one must be level 78, ultimate; level 90; and ultimate plus and beyond; the max level 100. The goal is to get armor pieces of the same kind in order to form a full set composed of four pieces. Then, once you get a full set, you get a set bonus which increases your overall stats as well as any resistances you have taken time to upgrade. Pros & ConsPros•A rewarding game environment in which other users collaborate and can farm items together while having fun smacking ogres, goblins, trolls and tough bosses together over and over towards mastery of different defense placements and setups•A nice dedicated community of people driven by their love and passion to see the game's survival•A tactful game that never gets boring, stale; there is always so much to do•Great trading community, armor types; rarities, characters and downloadable content worth every dollar you spend on it•Classes need to constantly be switched at the forge in game in order to place defenses, which usually one player on a good team does while the rest defendCons•Terribly addictive and when I mean terrible addictive, I mean to the point of ad nauseam due to the farming nature of the community divided half and half into the casual and then the hardcore dedicated regular players that farm every day and week•Hackers always present though there have been future steps in the sequel, Dungeon Defenders II to fully prevent hackers because they remodeled their servers to be client-side instead of server-side•Endless replayability •Each round can last up from forty-five minutes up to an hour per run on the top difficultyOverall 8 - I do  recommend it but be careful to the incredible addictive tendency of the game's elements, the trading system and the farming, darker side of the community    Overall, Dungeon Defenders is a family-friendly game for all the kids, teens and adults out there looking for something fun and endless to play in the role-playing and tower defense cross-platform genre. However, due to its constant persistence on the farming side of the community, it has inevitably led to its downfall and any chance of surviving. The community development team currently has been doing update after update to improve upon the game's features, maps, rewards and mechanics. However, this also means that those that are addicted to the game like I was can never leave it or it will be much harder to.  I have presented my views towards this over time towards the community and also questioned it in light of all the paradigms that have overtime posed a great emotional, cognitive, psychological and illicit response in the community. At first, my thoughts both towards Trendy Entertainment behind their support I found on Facebook upon Dungeon Defenders II when it was in early access stating that people needed to take off work to farm all day long after the new update they had made, I decided not to support a company like this whose hidden intention is to keep a dying user base at times constantly hooked and coming back. This is the reason why downloadable content in the early planning stages were released so rapidly to maintain that ambition and degree of pleasure over selfish greed, ambition and callous actions that promote a negative overall attitude in the community instead of humility and helping others before yourself. This alone led to people sometimes maintaining bragging rights and at the end of the time farming for virtual wealth while maintaining their own insecurities that some, though not all may have in  real-life.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2016
 Dungeon Defenders is a great game!	Firstly, there has been a lot of hate/reviews recently that downvote Dungeon Defenders (DD) because of the kerfuffle between Trendy and Wildcard.  This area is for  GAME       reviews not for  COMPANY	 reviews and fanboy/girl hate	Now on to the important thing, Dungeon Defenders is a relatively old game (considering the amount of new content released to steam every few months), However, that does not stop it from being, at least as far as im concerned, the greatest game of its genre.Now the graphics of DD are what I would describe as slightly "cartooney" and while that might not be some peoples first choice I believe its perfect for the game.The gameplay itself is quite nicely balanced accross all the difficulties (easy-insane) until you hit nightmare (the difference between medium and insane is the same as insane and nightmare) and the levelling system is pretty evenly scaled. Beating the game is quite possible both solo and playing online, it just requires a little bit of time. The gear system is one of my faviourite things about DD, that and having your own person tavern to show off the amazing loot you find. To play the game on all difficulties and succeed you definitly need the dlcs (at least the character ones) nightmare difficulty and tinkerers lab for some easy farming, but if you pick up on sale you get get it all for pretty cheap, and its worth the investment if you like the game as much as I have.Community wise the players are usually pretty fair, if you need any help or advice  DD Runs'n'Giveaways	 usually has people on that will gladly help you out or provide advice. Occasionally people will kick you without reason when joining a public game, or you will find the odd person with "hacked" gear. But as far as I'm aware these are just people who dont know how private games work and people who don't have the skill to beat the game without cheating. Also thanks to the hard work of the Community Development Team we've had 2 new patches this past year both with excellent maps and rewards as well as cheating players on the decline.When first getting into the game you may not find too many servers up, this is generally because of 1 or 2 reasons. Reason 1 theres no one on at that moment/your level is too low to see their games, Reason 2 the people that are on are playing private games not public games. This may be an older game yet somedays I'll open up the custom game browser and find a full page of games to join (and you can always host one yourself!). With over 700 hours in DD I think I have the experience first hand to safely recomend Dungeon Defenders to anyone interested!

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												Dungeon Defenders is a Action-RPG/Tower Defense hybrid, set in a light hearted fantasy world. The game is fun enough when played alone, but really shines when you grab 3 friends with you and experience the unique possibilities and synergies of the classes.The gameplay varies quite a lot from character to character, from the Apprentice that offers you basic tower defense gameplay to the Summoner (DLC) that plays more like an RTS. The vast variety of the gameplay styles of the characters and the RPG elements, such as leveling up your character and collecting better gear, offer great reply value. Many of the DLCs offer additional content that adds to the value of the game and thus buying the entire bundle is the most cost efficient way to get the best experience.Dungeon Defenders brings a more unique variant of the Tower Defense genre to the table, which makes it a great purchase for someone looking for a good co-op game and any fan of said genre.

Posted: December 14, 2016
												One of the greatest tower defense games of all time!This game takes into account a lot of features players enjoy.The ability to customize player statsWant to have 2 heroes dedicated to traps and have 1 dedicated to dps? You can do that! On top of that you can switch between heroes each wave to build traps and then switch to your dps hero.Tons and tons of content, this is a old game now and was continuely patched for a long time adding in more content to an extent that it is now hundreds of hours of content for players. Loot sharing! You can collect gear to customize with later, or even trade to your friends!Lastly, the game really incoporated solo vs party well, because traps matter so much you won't find yourself needing other players to contribute to attacking, you can solo the game just as easily as grouping. However! Grouping can have the upside of the fact it means you can switch all your best gear to 1 specific trapper and have everyone use different trappers with their best gear, rather than you spreading your gear out equally among your own trappers. This will make sense the more you play it, but they really did the game justice to solo/party balance.

number of helpful: 16 of 23 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												I picked Dungeon Defenders up during the holiday sale and had hoped it would be another decent tower defense game.  Ever since the Starcraft & Warcraft III (Cube Defense) days these kinds of titles have been able to deliver a lot of depth and strategy for relatively simple mechanics. Sadly, Dungeon Defenders failed in most of those aspects and felt a lot more like a cheap iPad knockoff of a good game.  The game has an arbitrary item drop system that constantly requires futzing with upgrades and switching between weapons - the RPGness of this title was disappointing to say the least. No tower mazing. Uninteresting weapons. Repetitive gameplay. Worst of all is the autoaim feature, which redirects shots in completely unanticipated ways - no option or mod exists to disable (WHY?). The game runs on the Unreal Engine 3, and it does look nice, so there's that. Play Sanctum 2 for a much better executed TD in a similar theme. If you want something hardcore just skip to Defense Grid for a proper TD. 4/10 for a very mediocre tower defense title.

number of helpful: 30 of 49 people (61%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												Magic towers? Check. Defensive auras? Check. Bombs? Check. Barriers? Check. Huge weapons? Check. Hordes of monsters waiting patiently behind strategically placed doors until players are ready? Check! Action RPG and tower defence hybrid Dungeon Defenders brings all those things to the table, plus more. It may not be the sharpest looking, musically creative, or thoughtful game out there, but it makes up for all of that by just being a lot of fun. Leaving their kids behind, the four legendary heroes of Etheria have set out to vanquish evil, loot caves and, if they're like most heroes, probably spend a fair bit of time in the local tavern. Their children, who had been content to stay behind and dream of adventure, accidently unleash an ancient power and soon find their castle surrounded by monsters. Crazy kids. True to their heritage, the young warriors take up their weapons and prepare to defend their home. The story is cute, but aside from a few brief cutscenes, largely irrelevant. The premise of Dungeon Defenders is simple: protect your crystal against hordes of monsters by building towers. There are four classes you can choose to play: the apprentice, who summons magic-shooting towers; the squire, who builds fortifications and medieval-style weaponry; the huntress, who lays traps and snares; and the monk, who can create auras to aid friends and hinder foes. Each class is diverse in their skills and abilities, and can be further customised each time they level up by assigning points to them, their towers, or both. In addition, there is a plethora of loot dropped each level that can give your heroes an edge in a fight. Even pets can be obtained to help you out! As you level up, new skill points are not your only advantage. All fortifications you build require mana for construction, which you can collect from treasure chests or fallen foes. Each time you level up, your maximum mana capacity increases. This allows you to store mana for repairs, upgrades and special class skills. Unfortunately, not all classes are created equal. As a team of four, the apprentice, squire, huntress and monk are a near unstoppable force of perfect complementary skills. Working individually, however, is a far different story. The apprentice and squire can hold their own, but if you prefer to play solo, you can say goodbye to much success with either the huntress or monk. There are 13 campaign maps in total (plus more through paid DLC), and each requires a new strategy. Early maps tend to have few chokepoints and only one crystal to defend, while later maps are a veritable maze of potential enemy paths, and may have up to four separate crystals. Maps can support up to four players (six on some of the DLC maps), and enemy health is scaled accordingly. As a result, you can tackle missions alone or online with friends and enjoy a challenge either way. Each set of maps has a unique feel. There are maps set inside servants' quarters, the throne room and the forge, while later challenges take you outside to the gardens or onto the roof. The cartoony, cel-shaded graphics are a delight and suit the light tone of the game well. Bright green gardens on one map are an excellent contrast to the dreary, rain-splattered turrets of another, and the diverse designs really set the maps apart from one another. Character faces look a little odd, but heroes are otherwise equally attractive; especially the apprentice, whose face is hidden beneath his pointy wizard hat. Unfortunately, different genders for each hero are only available as paid DLC. Bummer. Between maps, you return to your own special tavern, in which you can buy and sell equipment, organise your inventory or admire any achievements you earned, which take physical form as trophies. You visit the tavern of whoever is hosting the current game, which means you can show off to your friends, too! A word of warning though: in-game trophies can be earned in any mode, but achievements can only be completed through ranked online play. Annoying, but a necessary precaution considering the game is open to modding in offline or non-ranked play. Clearing all maps on medium takes around 15 hours, but there are three harder difficulties available (Hard, Insane, and Nightmare), complete with more powerful loot. Extra challenges are provided that mix things up too, such as a map where the crystal changes locations or where roles are reversed and you go on the attack. Many of these require multiple players though, so it's far more enjoyable if you can play with your friends. Online play functions amiably, but some further polish would have been beneficial. Joining or creating a game is easy enough, but at higher levels, I was often kicked the second I set foot into a game without explanation. Unlike many other multiplayer games, there is no voting system to kick people, so if one person has a problem with you, you're gone. There's no loot designation system either, so it's a free-for-all on the best drops. That said, most players are relatively blasé about gear and leave it alone to be auto-sold at the end of the round. On the bright side, the game natively supports voice chat. I may have initially been disappointed by the focus on online play, but these fears quickly passed as I discovered what an enjoyable game Dungeon Defenders is. 13 maps with 15-20 hours of play is a considerable amount of initial content, but the extra challenges and loot-hunting are what will keep you coming back. Working out strategies and tower placement is a great fun, and finally succeeding in your strategy is immensely satisfying. Some of the online features are a little rough, but if you enjoy a good tower defense game, then you should not miss this one.Highly Recommended

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												I should love this game.A tower defence game with heavy roleplaying elements, vibrant colours and plenty of different strategies to choose from.The core gameplay actually really speaks to me too. You control your hero, selected from 4 different types (or more, we'll get into that) and defend the Eternia Crystals using both an assortment of weapons and summoned magical defences.There are wizards that summon elemental towers, knights that summon medieval fortifications and siege weapons, monks that work with auras and hunters that employ traps.All of these feel different and entertaining, and for a first impression this game made a great one.The further you get from this core gameplay though, the bleaker things start to look.Your hero levels up by defeating enemies and surviving waves (or rather, having the crystal survive waves. Your hero just respawns if he/she dies), and gets a skill point or two to invest into either personal statistics like health or damage or choose to increase similar values on their summoned defences. This means that you have to choose how to balance things between your hero and your defences.Higher levels will also unlock access to better (randomly generated, typical RPG fare) loot, new defences and 2 special skills.Spare mana from levels, which is there used to summon, repair and upgrade defences, heal the player and use special skills, is given to the player and is then used to buy items from the shop in the tavern (hub level) or upgrade existing items. Both of these take a ton of mana, far more than you'll get just by progressing through the game normally. You'll need to grind a lot to afford your first pet, or max out even the shoddy level 1 gloves you're likely to have picked up during the opening level.Then there are 25 pieces of DLC for this game, total value ~5x times the cost of the base game that add new levels, new costumes and new heroes (some actually new ones but mostly gender-swapped reskins of the original 4 classes).There are three modes of playing this game, locally, online using the Steam system and 'Ranked' using Trendy's own in-house system. Ranked is the only way to earn achievements, and is completely separate from the rest of the game (characters, campaign progress, even camera settings) which pretty much negates all the neat Steam workshop stuff that's out there since everybody is playing Ranked instead.I first bought and played this game on XBox Live Arcade, which was almost entirely neglected by the development team. Not only did they not get most of the DLC, they were also passed over on actual game updates, including patches and bug fixes. For example, to this day the first Apprentice tower has a hard cap on its firing speed that makes it utterly useless for higher level players.More recently a semi-sequel came out, Dungeon Defenders Eternity, which repackaged all of the original content into a shiny new package... and expected people to just buy it again. Worse yet, that game has since been abandoned and just half-heartedly (and looking at the community comments, also just incompletely) compensated the disappointed players by giving them a free copy of Dungeon Defenders.I don't normally bother with things like that in a review, but their business practices really are abysmal, and the game would need to be a hell of a lot better for me to excuse them.So now there's an Early Access sequel in the works, which looks to add even more weird design choices and problems and I'm just done with all of it.Whatever is going wrong at Trendy Entertainment is going very wrong and I recommend everybody that will listen to watch it from a safe distance and not buy their games, including this one.Maybe get Defender's Quest instead, since that's also a tower defence rpg hybrid and it's actually good

 Not a game you'd want to play alone! Dungeon Defenders is an amazing multiplayer game that combines  both  Tower Defense and Action RPG. The game itself is amazing, good graphics, pets, 12 classes (4 Base classes, 8 DLC's), and a good storyline. After you finish the campaign, the challenges that you unlock are really fun, their like minigames. As a bonus, the ~20+ DLC's for the game make the challenges endless. Suggestions if you buy the game.  - Play with a friend!- Controller, ( not required but preferred )- Start with the character: Apprentice- Have fun!

content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												This game is the reason why I got Steam.Or really into PC gaming in general.After playing a little over 400 hours, I've done everything. I've killed the snowmen, I've spent afk hours sitting in a solo lobby farming coal, I've gotten everything.And then I got bored.In the beginning, this game was gold. It was the f***ing greatest game in my 11 year old mind. Then someone gave me a hacked weapon, and the game changed.So, I started hacking myself. The game got a lot funner, now that I had the ability to do whatever I wanted. I boosted people up, leveled them up, finished the game Nightmare Hardcore with random people, because I thought I was being nice.Eh, then the plague of being bored came again.One day I booted it up, just to see my trophies, and have my pride of an 11 year old. Turns out, It didn't boot up.I was banned.After being banned for hacking, I started to care less. But, because of the nastolgia, I decided to try my hardest to get unbanned, in case any friends would want to play with me. Long story short, I got unbanned. *wow, it's magic*I left the community for a good year, and came back to finish another 100 hours, then to leave it for good.But, now it's abandoned. Entirely. One person on a open server, 4 people on afk shops, hoping to get some mana for some items they farmed 30 seconds for.So, this is Dungeon Defenders now. I wish the Devs didn't abandon it. But, it was a good game for it's run. I still want to boot it up every so often, then someone calls me to play CS:GO.I would recommend it. Or would have about 3 years ago. If you can get some friends, and no one hacks, it's fun. It'll provide some good 500 hours, like it did for me. Just don't be an idiot, and remember: It's all about the game.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												I thought this game might possibly have some sort of potential before I played it and it had so many positive reviews I thought I couldn't really go wrong. All I learned was that the game doesn't really have much depth to it and how I couldn't understand why it had so many good reviews. The graphics are nice and colorful but the character models themselves look sort of ugly. Each class has their own unique sort of defenses though there are things I really don't understand about the game. One being some of the dlc characters, you've got some that are just the same characters that were already in the game except different gender... I didn't think the other dlc characters were that good either, the jester just lays ''presents'' around which are just random defenses, there's also the robot character which I thought was ok but the berserker might be the worst, he gets no defenses, he's just a melee oriented character and the best thing about this game is setting up your defenses while the melee is incredibly simplistic and not very good. The melee mostly revolves around holding down left click. Some people complain about the grinding but grinding wouldn't be bad if it were actually fun, in this game it isn't because of how repetitive it is and also when u make a character u can see the defenses u'll be able to use if u reach a certain level and there's five or so of them. I thought ''ok, so maybe new defenses will become available to me the longer I play'' but I was dead wrong, u use the same 5 the entire game and u can get to a rly high level above 60 I think so that's all that time grinding with the same 5 defenses the whole time, a severe lack in customization. I was expecting a good game but in the end I was disappointed. You also shouldn't bother with this game at all unless you have friends that are willing to play since this game is incredibly boring in single player and lots of random people whom you try to join will kick you out for no reason.

number of helpful: 17 of 29 people (59%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												This game is good while you dont hit the 'mythical floor', where you need to grind for good mythical gear to be able to grind transcendent gear to be able to grind supreme and ultimate gear. This grind could be fine for someone, until you discover that all good gear is probably hacked even on ranked steam server. All top results for every map is hacked, crazy gear is hacked/duped, cubes is massively duped, mana is hacked. Any 10 year kid's pc knowledge is enough to make mana infinite, to make insane items, etc. This game could be good if u just isolate yourself from rest of the hacked world, maybe with your friends, and just play from scratch till 70-s. Then the grind part starts, which is very-very VERY boring. You have to waste 2-3 hours to beat survival level to be able to find some mythical gear to be able to beat tavern defense level to be able to level so you can grind new levels to be able to grind...Achievements system is fine, it makes at least a little bit point to grind levels and gear, but nothing else.Graphics is a mess, cell-shading outlines looks like piece of shiТ (basically looks like LoL, which is also piece of shiТ, but even worse), massive special effects make your head sick, area of effect weapons is just impossible to watch. I just switch my monitor to white and black mode sometimes to play this game. Yeah. Its really, really sucks. If your pet hits with elemental damage, or your weapon is area of effect hit, you just cant see anything sometimes because of this explosions of whatever effect is. DLC-s is complete p2w madness. Half of them is absolutely required for beating game on nightmare difficulty (which is locked by the way, you need another DLC set to unlock it).Eternia shards DLC set costs the most and the most important part of DLC's. Without it the nightmare mode is locked, the only place you can start grind some nice gear and experience. Absolutely required.Series EV hero DLC is so overpowered that she can just do levels on insane difficulty from level one. Tower buff is completely overpowered and REQUIRED to any levels on nightmare. Summoner uses completely separate defense units which is called summon units, and has pretty overpowered defenses too, that also is required later. You CAN_NOT beat almost any levels on nightmare without this two heroes. Barbarian is one of the top dps heroes in game and he is required for some of the hardest maps in game to take down boss quickly. Jester is pretty weak compared to ev or summoner, but she still can be pretty op builder and good ranged dps hero. Also move tower ability sometimes helps. Tavern defense (anniversary pack DLC i believe?) is required for leveling and has insane pet as reward for beating it on a nightmare survival. EV lab is required for getting massive amount of insane accessories that you... get ready... CAN NOT GET ANYWHERE IN THE GAME EXCEPT ON THIS DLC, surprise! Also, it gives insane ultimate weapons on regular basis, crazy stats armor, lots of trans armor, sometimes even ult++ armor. New heroes DLC is required because this female hero versions have more movements speed so they are pretty much standard for builder hero. Talay mining complex DLC gives insane rewards for survival again (pet rock i believe?).Some Christmas map DLC gives you coal for beating it, which i believe if u have 100 of them (grinded or ... duped again), you can combine them to get the most insane pet in the game (all this pets is hacked if u find any for trade). I hope you get the point. If you want to really grind this game and spend lots of time on it, this P2W DLC is absolutely required. I dont recommend this game for almost everyone. However, if you and your friends desperate to find any co-op game to play, you might try this. Wait for sale and take your chances.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2016
												Although several years old, and followed by one sequel (Dungeon Defenders 2) and one re-imagining (Dungeon Defeners Eternity), the original Dungeon Defenders is still a ton of fun.  While it can be played solo, the real fun of this game is playing co-op with at least one other person, and coordinating your defenses.  A long and grindy game, to be sure, but plenty of fun on the journey.  A very tongue in cheek art style, as well as pop culture references everywhere: on some maps, the reward for completion is a Monk staff that looks like Darth Mauls' double-light sabre, while on another, you get a chainsword right out of Warhammer 40K.On sale the entire collection, including DLCs, will run you about $10, which when you see how many hours you'll sink into it, is a huge value.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2016
												Dungeon Defenders is probably the BEST GAME EVUR!!! (probably not, but it's awesome, really)You are reading the review of someone who was able to play this game before the modders came and began their work of pure evil. If you don't have the DLCs you get to choose between the Archer, Monk, Apprentice and Squire.The archer-class focuses mainly on traps and, well, physical long-range attacks as she is an archer-class hero.The monk-class is balanced between long- and short-range attacks and can create auras (spheres) that have various effects on the enemies.The apprentice-class is a magic long-range fighter able to build magic towers and one type of blockade.The squire-class is the tank in this game as he has to fight in close-range combat and can summon various weapons that cause physical damage to nearby enemies.Most of the players tend to choose the "Monk" because of his balance, but you definitely miss out if you play only one hero-class. You get to know the advantage and disadvantages of every single hero and learn to combine them to master this game.Enough talk for now, go and hunt some goblins!!!

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
												This is a great bang-for-the-buck game that combines tower defense and first (or third) person shooter ideas into a fun little package. Worth catching while on sale. Fun to play with friends.The under-advertised feature of being able to do local drop-in and drop out co-op with up to four players is a GREAT feature... and one I didn't even know was possible until someone mentioned it in game. You can utilize this with both offline AND online play. It's also a great way to power-level your own characters! Have a big bad level 80+ and you want to get a different class up in level and gear quickly? Plug in a Xbox 360 or Xbox One controller, hit start, and let them idle on a hard map you've mastered a defense build for.... Maybe even slap a rubber band on the shoot button, and let the game's auto-targeting hit anything somewhat in front of your lowbie. (The game seems to auto-target assist with a control pad by default... though not with a mouse and keyboard.)The story isn't particularly great, though it is a nice touch. Once you figure out the "trick," many of the maps are pretty easy (though figuring out the best way to utilize your limited points for building defenses is one of my favorite aspects of the game.)Unfortunately, there are points in the game where you will likely hit a gear curve, forcing you to repetatively grind a previously beaten map on increasingly harder difficulty settings to unlock better gear. Later levels and especially the expansion can be VERY challenging on "nightmare" difficulty. Or, you can look around at other player's shops and try to find some gear to buy. (Sadly, most players GROSSLY overprice the gear in their personal shops.)The ability to unlock and select difficulty levels for maps is a definate plus. The 6 hero types (I'm not counting the mostly the same gender "alternatives") allow for different approaches to the maps, though true master builders will learn to combine the tower / defense types to really clobber harder levels and higher difficulty settings (a small hint: BUFF BEAM).I spent a ton of time in this game and originally caught it a long time ago for like $5. It's been one the best game purchases I've made in terms of value alone. It's a pretty fun little game to boot. Go buy it already.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
Updated ReviewAfter more than 6,000 hours in this game the day has come to quit Dungeon Defenders. Easy to imagine that I've given a recommendation before. Unfortunately recent updates made by the Community Development Team (CDT) ruined the game - at least for me.To my knowledge the CDT has been introduced to fix bugs, adding quality-of-life changes such as new content. Instead they also change core mechanics of the game such as RNG, towers and enemies. Things we were used for long 5 years are getting changed out of the sudden because certain individuals within the CDT are enforcing their changes more or less.Changes which results into non-working builds which worked for such a long time, changes which are not though-out well enough in regard to low and mediocre players. The exclusive focus to change things for high-end / meta players is a shame to say the least.The game has worked just fine for 5 years, players who are involved within the CDT have played the game themselves several thousands hours just fine. If the game needed such drastic changes, they all wouldn't have spent so much time in a "bad" game. Sadly a lot of them forget or ignore their past history within Dungeon Defenders.Fighting after every update to keep Trendy's Dungeon Defenders became extremely tiring over time. Discussing with people who have played a game several thousands of hours is somewhat pointless when they are still thinking that they have to progress in any form or shape. There is a point when you have completed a game, when you play a game because it does fun to play instead of trying to progress further.The RNG got changed due to requests of players who have played a lot of hundreds of hours. They wanted more higher quality drops for some reasons, even though Mythical and Transcendent quality was enough. Result: The categorization of drops were changed. While you have seen regularly Transcendent armor with 280 or more upgrades including good stats, now you are lucky to see a Transcendent armor piece with more than 200 upgrades. Most Transcendent stuff ends up with upgrades from 110 to 150. Also Supreme and Ultimate drops with upgrades from 180 to 200. Sadly people focus so much on quality tags that they completely ignore actual item stats. We are miles away from the drops we had before v8.1.Towers has been changed too. Unfortunately the CDT decided to start with a Hero which was already superior compared to all other beginner classes and made him more superior. The explanation was that they had to start somewhere. True, but not with current strongest! They also stated that every tower should become a viable choice, which sounds more like "build-whatever-you-want" considering the superior position of the Hero they started with since a "nerf" will be not discussed. I don't know about you but I belief that towers don't have to be useful across the game. If you pass a certain point it is good that you are in need to build different than you did on previous difficulties.Enemy mechanics has been changed. Golden enemies have received a massive boost across the board. Instead of a 15% in health and strength they received a boost of 500%! People already disagreed to this while the beta was out for testing but concerns were completely ignored. Now we experience broken builds which worked so long for campaign and especially for survival. If you had to fight a golden Wyvern with 9.2m before, you are facing now Wyvern which are dealing 5 times more damage while having 40m health. Since they don't really interact with your defenses, they fly straight forward to your crystal. For high-end / meta players not a big deal but for every mediocre player. The ones of you who played with lower stats back in the days will remember sudden crystal explosions caused by golden enemies.All this results into one important thing; Reaching high-end / meta status has been made more difficult.Last but not least, many changes has been performed which will encourage and make the life of hackers easier. I'm talking about changes like allowing to build into spawns, higher survival starting waves (almost no legit player is able to deal with), adding new maps and NM achievements behind a "grind"-wall.I would have preferred when the CDT concentrated on bugfixes and new content. My interest in this game was huge, hence all the guides, tips and tricks I've provided. Too bad.Original ReviewRecommended with an agreement of ~80% (~250 of 200 found this useful)At first I was not interested into this game so I purchased it for my brother. Played once I had to purchase it for myself. I never have played an more addictive game, though I like the Tower Defense genre a lot. I don't think I need to write much more about the game due to my playtime of this game.If you like Tower Defense then you have to play this game. It is frequently on sale so keep an eye at the stores of Steam, GMG, Humble Bundle and others.Note: Be aware that the Linux and Mac version of this game has a few issues. I strongly advise to play it on a windows machine.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 3, 2012
												Belated review. Dungeon Defenders is one of the best action-tower defense games I have played. The gameplay is much like other games in the genre - progress through a series of levels in which your goal is to defend a crystal. The catch is the crystal is under attack by waves of enemies. Between waves you have the opportunity to set up defenses (different types are available depending on which of the 4 characters you use). Once a wave starts, it's you and your defense versus the horde... rinse and repeat. So what sets DD apart? Well, one cool thing is that you create and play as a personalized character that can be saved. Your character levels up via experience gained and can be equipped with hundreds of different weapons that are found during levels. Add in an excellent online co-op mode, tons of extra challenges and DLC, and you've got a damn near perfect package. Give this a shot, even if you've never tried tower defense before... but don't blame me if you become addicted! :)

content:
Posted: August 1, 2013
												It's good. Would be an even more fun game if it could be played as intended. Instead, you have all manner of hackers and cheats running rampant on the Ranked servers (the Open servers don't even pretend to enforce the rules) to the point that you literally can't have a game without someone tainted by illegitimate play joining, be it someone who hacks or has been given items/mana by someone who does.In addition, individual hosts can kick (read: ban) players from their game at any time, which they can and will do frequently and without warning, reason, or provocation. You can reasonably expect to be kicked from games multiple times per play session, and never know why.That said, both issues do not exist if you play primarily solo, with friends, or as a host. It's a pretty solid game that is still supported by a dev team, has community events on a regular basis, and generally pretty fun to play. There are a large variety of maps, heroes, and ways to play. Early, mid, and late game progression all play completely differently from one another, and they're all worth experiencing in my opinion.I've been told the DLC system is not great, but I personally picked it up with all DLC from the Humble Bundle, so I honestly couldn't tell you with any degree of certainty what things are available without DLC. Many maps and the Nightmare difficulty require DLC to start from your own Tavern, but can be played without owning the DLC. All of the most recent updates (and at this point, presumably all future updates) are all free, with all heroes besides the base four being DLC.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
												I'm here to finally write my review on this game, as I have started to play it again after a substantial amount of time away. To be quite blunt, the game plays fairly well, and progress is fairly linear throughout the main maps of the game, however, that is where the hand-holding stops. Upon finally defeating your big, friendly, final boss and the basic challenges, those who bought the DLC are in for a pleasant treat of hours upon hours of grinding. Don't get me wrong, this is actually a good thing; you are forced to take your old strategies and constantly improve them to conquer nightmare mode, and you will reap the reward for this effort, but this, while to me being a fun grind, may be to others, simply dull. This is where I talk about the community of Dungeon Defenders; there are still many high level players who are friendly enough to help out newer players to get started, be it early game, or nightmare mode, they are there. That being said, this community is still very friendly, and most of them will be there to help you out if you ask for it. All in all, I'll rate this game positive, with my long, dull review. There have been many changes since the community took over development that I dislike, and balance issues are nowhere near being addressed in an orderly fashion, but the feel this game brought me from day one still remains, and that is what truly matters to me.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2013
												Reviews for the Deaf and Hard of HearingWith regard to accessibility for deaf/hoh gamers, I give Dungeon Defenders an 8/10.GameplayThere appear to be visual cues to most (if not all) events in the game. The screen does get very cluttered, though, and it can become easy to miss a key visual such as your crystal being attacked, which can lead to losing a game. This event is accompanied by a sound for HOH gamers.Subtitles/TextDungeon Defenders has a storyline that plays in cutscenes. When you turn captions on, the cutscenes will be the only time that you see the subtitles, as the gameplay does not require them.Chatting/CommunicatingDungeon Defenders has voice chat. In my experience so far, most people do not seem to use it, though, and prefer to type. There are no key combinations or voice binds to convey messages quickly, so you will need to type if you cannot hear/speak.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												I highly enjoy and recommend this game. It is not just your average defense oriented game. Especially when playing by yourself it gets to be pretty challenging to where everyone is coming from everywhere and you can only be at one place at a time. Its fun, addictive, strategical, and just awesome. It is definitely worth the 15$. I would recommend it to anyone that likes a little challenge, or even a lot of challenge. There is such a variety of everything that is available. Every class is different in the play style and uses. Every class is going to have a different set up of blockade/towers. The designs are very well done and the level designs are fantastic. The laning is very simple, but still requires thought in where to put towers and blockades along the way. One thing I do have to say about this that never really is established with info, Steam Achievements are only availible by doing the Trendy Ranked servers. You will not be able to earn them on Local play or Open play. I realized that after getting some in game achievements and not getting any Steam achievements.

												Dungeon Defenders is a co-op focused tower defense game where four heroes try to stop huge monster waves from destroying magic crystals by building all kinds of defensive structures such as walls and cannons. There are also some roleplaying and hack & slash elements so players can level up their heroes and fight enemies with swords and spells. The singleplayer side of the game is lacking but the multiplayer mode is always very fun and addicting. Technically the game is quite polished and doesn't have any fatal bugs which is always a good thing.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												Let's see if I can put my thoughts together on this...When I first heard about Dungeon Defenders I was incredibly excited. I've loved Tower Defense games for a while and always been a fan of Co-Op games. So when I heard there was a Co-Op Tower Defense RPG coming out I couldn't wait! Once my friends and I got our hands on it we had a blast. Sure it had some problems... Squires were OP, Survival was too easy, ranged enemies would attack behind the spawn shield... but it was really fun! Eventually the first part of their  expansion  came out, that's when things went downhill.Trendy decided to add a new difficulty level in their expansion, since players thought the game was too easy. On "Nightmare" difficulty Player/Tower stats were altered to make the game more  balanced . A new item tier "Mythical" was added for Nightmare, presumably to incentivize playing it. Which sounds good until you find out Mythical items had massively inflated stats, trivialising past content. Though to be fair, getting said gear incredibly difficult. Drop rates on Mythical were very low on all but the hardest maps. Seeing how those maps were balanced around you having Mythical gear, pretty much the only way to get the gear was to join someone who was hardcore and farmed early maps for it or was also carried.Did I forget to mention they added new enemies for Nightmare? The Spider was the first one they added. Having a new set of (invisible) spawn locations, chosen to backdoor common defense locations, they would web towers drastically reducing fire rate and increasing the damage they would take.  Thankfully  spiders would prioritize players, webbing them and reducing movement speed, attack rate as well as preventing the use of abilities. Djinn were the second ones added, flying enemies that have the ability to "instantly" destroy defenses with a cast time based on what tier the defense was. Also possesing the ability to buff enemy units, turning them gold and making them significantly stronger. Sharken were the third, having the ability to charge through defenses pushing them out of the way. Probably the least obnoxious of the new enemies. Lastly the Goblin Copter, flying enemies that would spawn from Wyvern spawn locations. They would spawn carrying an Ogre and proceed to fly somewhere on the map and drop them off. If you made the mistake of not killing it before then, it would proceed to fire player seeking missiles, anti-tower flares and rockets at players/defenses. They also made Ogres much more common on Nightmare, in case all the previous wasn't enough.Trendy, confident in their new found balance, proceeded to add new maps with this in mind. Basically having the difficulty options be varying differences of Nightmare difficulty, new enemies included. Most of the maps they added were well designed (some not so much). Unfortunately to play these maps you have to own them (shocker). To be fair, Trendy had this odd business model of having (most) maps be free the first two weeks after their release. Now a days you have to buy them and there are A LOT of them.They also added some new classes, Barbarian for pure melee DPS, Series EV able to wield two ranged weapons and use an  adjustable  wall and a buff beam, Summoner for pure builders with  movable  towers and Jester for pure ranged DPS and minor trolling. Though the first classes they added were gender swapped versions of the vanilla heroes, with slightly different abilities. All of these you had to pay for as well, though I'd say they're all worth it (excluding the gender swaps).Overall, Trendy hit gold with this game and did a pretty good job at keeping it alive. Personally I don't like what Nightmare did to the game but I think they had a lot of good ideas. Dungeon Defenders is definitely a game worth playing, if you haven't for some reason. Just make sure you get some friends to play it with and don't expect to play all the maps unless you're REALLY into it. DLC strongly recommended.Also Trendy seems to have granted a community team the ability to officially update the game, so maybe we'll see some cool stuff out of that.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												Tower defense mixed with third person hack and slash.  Awesome game over all.The game is great for at least 40 hours of game play if not more even if you aren't being obessive about upgrades and loot drops.  I ended up playing this single player a great deal of time when I first got it and even before I burned out I played mostly single player, that being said it's great fun to get a group of friends together and run over hoards of goblins and making strategies that fail, bearly work, or are overly powerful.  Expirmentation and variation are great.The early game and mid game are great for casual gamers.  Some thing to pick up and go.  Hammer out the easy/normal/hard difficulties for fun, leveling up characters and weapons has a fairly decent curve and is enjoyable for most skill levels.  It can be a heck of a challenge for those who try to jump into hard content from a low level or a smooth ride for those who just progress naturally.The late game is a bit tedious... I'm talking after you beat the normal difficulties and normal maps.  When you get into the advanced content it gets to be a giant pain in the butt to grind for good weapons and armor, trading is a nightmare and the amount of mana to upgrade anything is absolutly insane.  Playing with people at the higher levels is also very aggrivating.  The late game was designed to be very hard, and it is.  It's also for only for the stout hearted.All of that being said I highly recommend picking up this game on sale or not.  If you like tower defense or hack n' slash you'll probably like this game.  The late game shouldn't put you off because you can easily put in 40 hours or more before you get to late game content if you're just looking for a game to enjoy.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2016
												I do not know the whole back story behind the studio and ARK and I do not care. I am reviewing this game purely as a game by itself.I picked this up through Humble Bundle almost a year ago and didn't actually play it till recently. Its a creative tower defense game that is more or less designed to be played with multiple people. You could, in theory single player it but then you would be grinding a LOT to get your characters to a certain level.Online play I do not think I can recomend, there is basically no servers....but you get that a lot with some older steam games. Local Co-Op (or Lan, or playing with people you personally know online) I can definately recommend. Me and my wife and some of my friends head over to my house to play this as a couch co-op game all the time and its a butt tonne of fun. My wife ussually doesn't play video games "unless you can raise a baby in them" (sims, harvest moon, pokemon (yeah I don't get that last one either)) and she loves playing this game with me.All in all, not a terrible game. Not an amazing game for full price. But not a terrible one. I recomend doing what I did and waiting till its on a bundle, or through a steam sale and treating it as a "Local Couch multiplayer game"

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												This game was probably the most value for money purchase I have ever made. I have sunk countless hours into this game (I lied.. steam counted 737..) and it has provided me with hours of fun, a great community and a lot of interesting gameplay. The game itself is a 3rd person tower defence game with an rpg element to it. Your hero levels up and gets new items that drop from the monsters you kill. The loot is randomly generated which in itself has a good and a bad side. The good side being BAJILLIONS of armor/weapon variants. The down side is that getting good quality loot and more importantly loot that you need and are looking for is very difficult, especially when you get to the higher rarity armor and weapon types. This can make the game very grindy and if doing levels over and over again, perfecting your layout and gameplan isn't for you then Dungeon Defenders isn't for you, at least not if you want to be the very best like no one ever was..That being said there are a lot of levels, challenges, maps and various modes to play giving the game enough variety and interesting gameplay to warrent anyone playing it for the price. There are some big flaws with the game. The prime of these boil down to two things; There is a lot of DLC, and I do mean a lot of it, and the game is very easy to hack. Now the DLC aspect of the game isn't too terrible. There is a lot of it but a lot of it is cosmetic and almost all of them are cheap. Now the hacking is an actual problem. The game is very easy to hack and hence hackers are prominent in the community, even in the online play. Trendy tries to monitor and ban hackers but it is a bit out of their control. If you are the kind of person who likes to play by themselves (which you totally can) then this won't affect you at all. If you want to play online with others then I suggest using the forums and getting to know a few people who play the game (or get your friends to play with you). Having people you regularly play with ensures a nicer experience then trying to adapt to pub games and risk having your experience ruined by hackers. With all this in mind I still feel like Dungeon Defenders was a great purchase and a great experience. I would recommend it to anyone if for nothing else just to play through the story and see the interesting gameplay it provides. This game is old however and the sequal is on its way so perhaps holding off for that may be a better idea if you don't plan on getting into this game hardcore.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
												OH MY GOODNESS I LOVE THIS GAME!!!!You have a choice of four classes at the beginning, Squire, Apprentice, Monk, and Huntress.- The Squire is mainly melee- the Apprentice can lay down offensive defenses- the Monk has ranged and melee attacks, but weak defenses, making him harder to play- and the Huntress has a powerful ranged attack, but less defensesIt's really fun to go through mowing down enemies, and that brings me to my next point, enemy variation.Enemies come in about 12 different types, such as goblins, elf archers, orcs, ogres, wizards, and so on. But, each enemies can also have an element assigned to it, so it deals that element's damage, and is invicible to that element. It adds more strategy to leveling up you weapon, instead of putting all of the points into fire. Also, each enemies can be assigned a difficulty, such as easy, medium, or hard, which increase health and damage.The leveling system is great. You have ten base stats. TEN. They are split up into hero stats, defense boosts, and abilities. Hero stats include Health, Damage, Speed, and Casting Rate, which increase your heroes killing potential. Defense Boosts are like the hero stats, but for your defenses, so you can increase fire rate, health, damage, and area of effect. Abilities you unlock later in the game, but you can assign stats points to those to increase damage.I don't want to spoil the story, so I'll just go to my next point.This game is one of the few current-gen games to get DLC right. No doubt. You can use DLC to buy new hero classes, which shake up the gameplay, new map packs, and even an extension to the story. But all of this is optional. You don't have to buy any of it. You can still enjoy the full game for the price you see on Steam.There is no doubt that this is one of my favorite games of all time.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												I love this game. Fun to play alone, or with others. I just wish more people got online and played!! Most people online are nice. A lot of kids, but that is expected. I noticed it's hard to join low level people's games with a high level character. Which is why more people need to play this game for a variety of players. I host games often because of gettiing kicked, and allow all level characters to join most of the time.  Personally, I think modified weapons are great if you want to breeze threw the maps or have a more relazing experience. I would not recommend always playing with these modified weapons, because it takes away from the excitement of this colorful and sometimes challenging game. Challenge games are fun... and well, challenging. I recommend playing on hard once you get the hang of the game, because it's the right amount of difficulty and enemies in my opinion. I love playing on Insane, but I've put a lot of hours in this small addicting game. I play started out playing with keyboard and mouse, but i like to use a controller now. Using a controller is easier once you figure out how to build towers. I recommend this game, but be careful not to get sucked in and spend a bunch of money. I hear it's very easy to do.

content:

												If you had any doubts about this game, Leave them at the door. This game may not seem like much, But it takes a new twist of gameplay. Combing action RPG combat with Tower Defence Stratagy. After I sat down and played it for an extended peroid of time I fell in love with this game. To put it simply. There are so many weapons, armors and pets it's not even funny. 4 player co-op campain (and in some cases 6) the game isn't too story driven but it does have a nice story. Unlike a normal tower defence game you take control over your hero during the combat phase and fight enemys in real time, Be in over the shoulder third-person, First person or eagle eye view it satisfies it all. This game gets a 10/10 from me. I do reccomend it do anyone.

												I absolutely Love Dungeon Defenders.I have spent a lot of time playing the xbox 360 version with my mates.Its blend of tower defence with rpg character building and loot grinding hooked me in for many. many, many hours.However i had heard that the PC version was even better on account bof having more expansion packs, characters etc. so i bought it when the Collection was on sale for £9.99 and playing the game i love as the new  summoner class has made it new and refreshing again.its a brilliant game, however i will say this, it is definitely more fun with friends than with randoms or on your own!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												Ah, Dungeon Defenders. Great tower defense game, the best one I've played in my life.You'll start off rather slow, which is why you'll mainly want to bring along friends or get boosted by said friends. If you're still enjoying the game after a good while, chances are your experience will become a lot better as your opportunities begin to expand.The game won't be offering you an alarming number of handouts. Expect long (and later on challenging) fights, as well as trial and error.Ultimately, this game is a grindfest. If you're going to buy Dungeon Defenders with the goal to progress and grow mighty, then I STRONGLY recommend that you purchase the DLC's for this game as it grants you access to heroes which you'll hands down need to climb your way up as well as maps that contain the many items you'll be after eventually.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2011
												I am so glad they added mouse freelook support for the pc. Steam version probably has the best exclusives, giving you 4 familiars which have op unique abilities. The game itself allows for very different style/gameplay depending on which character you choose. The Melee characters are probably the easiest to start off with since your strongest attack is your melee weapon and don't need to worry too much about mana. The ranged characters need to worry about keeping up their traps/spells/buildings but once you plan out your attacks you will know how to place things correctly and can basically keep out of battle while your buildings/traps do all the work for you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												For the initial price, Dungeon Defenders (DD) provided way more value for your money than most games.  If they had stopped there, the game would have been insanely popular.But they started releasing tons of 'tweaks' that changed things by (usually) 30-40%.  Changes on such a scale are a bad idea, and quickly unbalanced everything.  Months later, the changes now seem to be fairly stable...  If it weren't for all the DLC.See, the DLC tends to add further unbalancing changes.  And the cycle continues, over and over.Buy this game for the original content, and try not to be disturbed by the changes.  It's immensely fun.And if you buy the DLC, expect it to be horribly unbalanced.Also, bring friends, or play solo.  PUGs in this game are the worst ever.
