content:
Posted: June 12, 2012
												If you had any doubts about this game, Leave them at the door. This game may not seem like much, But it takes a new twist of gameplay. Combing action RPG combat with Tower Defence Stratagy. After I sat down and played it for an extended peroid of time I fell in love with this game. To put it simply. There are so many weapons, armors and pets it's not even funny. 4 player co-op campain (and in some cases 6) the game isn't too story driven but it does have a nice story. Unlike a normal tower defence game you take control over your hero during the combat phase and fight enemys in real time, Be in over the shoulder third-person, First person or eagle eye view it satisfies it all. This game gets a 10/10 from me. I do reccomend it do anyone.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2012
												Dungeon Defenders is a really fun game to just pick up and play.  It doesn't take long to jump right in and start having fun.  After a short introduction, you're thrown into the action, and with a myriad of different classes, anyone can find their niche and play the role they enjoy most.  Grab a few friends and play together, join a game with random other players, or even try to tackle it solo.  The difficulty scales as your level does, and with the added depth of customization to characters, as well as your items, you'll keep finding reasons to grind down waves of monsters to defend your dungeon.  Definitely worth picking up.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2012
												Dungeon Defenders is a really fun game to just pick up and play.  It doesn't take long to jump right in and start having fun.  After a short introduction, you're thrown into the action, and with a myriad of different classes, anyone can find their niche and play the role they enjoy most.  Grab a few friends and play together, join a game with random other players, or even try to tackle it solo.  The difficulty scales as your level does, and with the added depth of customization to characters, as well as your items, you'll keep finding reasons to grind down waves of monsters to defend your dungeon.  Definitely worth picking up.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2011
												An awesome mix of tower defense and action-RPG. The tower defense and action-RPG aspects blend wonderfully, as there are class and character building choices for every sort of player. Someone who is more akin to setting up a line of defenses could pick the Apprentice (a very strong defensive structure class) and put their skills into making their defenses better. Someone who wants more action and wants to kill enemies themselves could pick the Huntress (fantastic dps class) and put their skills into making their character's stats better.Although you play the same missions a lot of times over, they manage to be dynamic with different difficulty levels, very unique classes, and the billions of possible equipment options.The only major flaws I've encountered with this game are disconnections from the online play server and disconnections from hosts themselves; however, Trendy's been working hard to get this stuff fixed.This game is amazing and I recommend it as a must buy.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2011
												I am so glad they added mouse freelook support for the pc. Steam version probably has the best exclusives, giving you 4 familiars which have op unique abilities. The game itself allows for very different style/gameplay depending on which character you choose. The Melee characters are probably the easiest to start off with since your strongest attack is your melee weapon and don't need to worry too much about mana. The ranged characters need to worry about keeping up their traps/spells/buildings but once you plan out your attacks you will know how to place things correctly and can basically keep out of battle while your buildings/traps do all the work for you.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2012
												Great Game... Constant New Content...Need Anything Else?Best way I can describe it is that a 3rd person shooter and a tower defense game mixed into one amazing game. You set up defense towers, while you also run around and kill goblins yourself. Each class has their own towers/traps and weapons, a variety team makes the difference. Solo this game is ok, but playing with people online or, better yet, your friends makes this one game I can't stop playing. So much DLC it gets costly to get it all, but it is money well spent on a game like this.Pros:+Game-play+Group play+A lot of new content (now that DD2 is coming out, I expect it to stop adding to this game)+Many characters and missions+Level designs+Can set up a shop to sell equipment and pets+Lots of AchievementsCons:-Solo play-Can get repetitive at times (especially playing solo)-There can be glitches (goblin stuck in wall and mage hiding in door for example, however game will kill them after a couple minutes)So-So:=Graphics (they are good, but not amazing)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												I'm not usually one for tower defense, but the place/upgrade towers AND run around and fight enemies yourself is a really well done mechanic. This game also has a really great difficulty curve, where you feel really comfortable playing through slightly lower level content, or you can push yourself to try higher difficuty/higher levels. Fantastic Co-op, great loot progression, and a fun art style really make this game worthwile.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												This has to be the most fun game I have ever played. The intricate mechanics are superb, the level design is both challenging and balanced, well tested with almost zero faults, the sheer volume of numbers and just how quickly the engine of the game calculates the smooth loot drops with superbly balanced, well designed non faulting algorithms [number of mobs defeated in total * (number of mobs defeated personally + amount of damage done in total) / 1 = Stats Level on next drop] means that you get perfectly balanced, well designed, non faulting, algorithm crafted balanced perfectly loot that's been well designed.The action is simply scintillating with almost no down time for a breath and the games design that's both perfect and well balanced means that the grind of a normal moba such as DotA 2 or Team Fortress 2 just simply isn't there. Over all I'd certainly recommend this well designed, perfectly balanced game that is well balanced and perfectly designed over and over again to literally, physically and metaphorically everyone, 0/10 Damp Fanny - The Outgoing Otaku

content:
Posted: July 15, 2012
												Dungeon Defenders is a really fun game to just pick up and play.  It doesn't take long to jump right in and start having fun.  After a short introduction, you're thrown into the action, and with a myriad of different classes, anyone can find their niche and play the role they enjoy most.  Grab a few friends and play together, join a game with random other players, or even try to tackle it solo.  The difficulty scales as your level does, and with the added depth of customization to characters, as well as your items, you'll keep finding reasons to grind down waves of monsters to defend your dungeon.  Definitely worth picking up.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2013
												Great strategy game really! It's super fun to play :)As you go into the game you are greeted by a nice introduction to the story. Basically the story is about 4 children left to tend the castle by their parents while they go off. One of the young ones breaks a crystal which releases 'The Old One' or the great evil. Your mission would be to protect the crystals from evil creeps by building towers or by using your weapons and amazing skills to fight them off. The journey wont be easy, so you would want to grab a friend or make one in the game.You will join the game and create a character. It is recommended to create on Ranked as there are less people who mod weapons on there. If you didn't buy any DLC then you would start off with the 4 main classes which are Squire, Apprentice, Huntress and Monk. In the time I played this game I really enjoyed it. I enjoyed the great community which comes along with it and some great gameplay. I'll try not to be bias but it's hard to when you are literally in love with the game.If you like strategy, tower defense, leveling up your charactes, grabbing loot, selling, trading then this game might be just for you. It contains a pretty good storyline which drags you in to see what happens next and some great DLC. The downside is that it takes a long time to become powerful enough to complete alot harder challenges as in all leveling and loot games. It will take time to find good loot and some runs to do so. One wont be enough, you will need to do more as you will probably need to equip all of your characters as with one it will be hard.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 7, 2012
												Well, I originally wrote a review recommending the game to people, but the game has essentially become a giant 1,000 hour farmfest to even be able to get into any of the newer maps within the game. The original concept was amazing and well put together, but Nightmare on newer maps is a neverending raise to get your specific classes to have just the right stats to be able to scrape through by the skin of your teeth. It's not going to be a pleasant or rewarding experience at this point.Updates upon updates intended to just prolong the life of the game without adding anything meaningful to it really ruined the appeal for most players. I found myself spending less time playing the game as a result of this and don't really like the fact that there are maps I consistently farmed a while ago being completely impossible because of new additions to the game; these are maps I was able to do on the difficulty that have been reworked by simply dropping giant ogres on top of my defenses. That's not difficulty, that's just adding stuff for the sake of adding stuff and making things more difficult just to try to get people to continue playing the game.Too many games are going this route at this point. When it is just an endless grind, only the most dedicated are going to stay and they are not going to be happy. DD was definitely a great game, but if you're looking for something that is completely enjoyable and rewarding, don't get this game. That is, unless you're OK with playing the original version of the game. That is actually enjoyable and requires some thought in how you handle certain things. It's enjoyable.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												For the initial price, Dungeon Defenders (DD) provided way more value for your money than most games.  If they had stopped there, the game would have been insanely popular.But they started releasing tons of 'tweaks' that changed things by (usually) 30-40%.  Changes on such a scale are a bad idea, and quickly unbalanced everything.  Months later, the changes now seem to be fairly stable...  If it weren't for all the DLC.See, the DLC tends to add further unbalancing changes.  And the cycle continues, over and over.Buy this game for the original content, and try not to be disturbed by the changes.  It's immensely fun.And if you buy the DLC, expect it to be horribly unbalanced.Also, bring friends, or play solo.  PUGs in this game are the worst ever.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2013
												This is a pretty nice blend of tower defense and action-RPG. If you have a craving to farm for good loot, there's plenty of it to be had with this game. The biggest drawback I've found is the difficulty curve. Easy, Medium, Hard and Insane are easy enough to do through the core campaign but if you want to tackle Nightmare, you'll have to do a lot of farming for much better equipment as well as grinding experience to get to a level where you can actually equip such gear, otherwise you'll end up being a burden to your team in the "endgame" maps. If you get into it, be sure to get some friends down the road because it can get pretty boring playing solo. Overall, I find it to be a pretty enjoyable and addicting game and I'm glad I picked it up on the cheap thanks to the Humble Bundle!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2015
												Dungeon Defenders - Your everyday tower defense game.There is a very big reason why I recommend this game - It is possibly the only game that my wife and I can play together without going at each other throats.The background (story - if you can even call it that) is quite simple. The heroes go away for blood and glory, leaving the apprentices behind. As any proper apprentice does, they messed up and now hordes of orcs are invading you from every corner to destroy the Eternia Cristals and unleash a new latent evil).So long story short - you have a cristal and you have to defend it at all cost.The positives:+ Very fluid game+ Different Classes with unique traps and tricks+ Nice cartoonish characters+ Smooth Learning curve+ Can be amazingly challenging, depending on how you play it+ Nice to play with friends and familyThe negatives- Can be repetitive (after 60h of game I am still loving it, but I can understand why people would say that)- Very segmented in DLCs. It is frustrating when you realize that you only have 50% of the game, and the other 50% is in DLCs.- Playing on-line with strangers is not very fun. Strangers dont tend to play as a team and the game becomes more a race to see who plants more of their own traps. Furthermore, higher levels will have no trouble outshining the lower level players.My personal experience:I have 2 characters - one in which I have been using to play alone (full single player, without even mixing classes) and other that I use to play with my wife.My experience as single player - From what I read - and from what I believe it is the way the game was built to be played, when going single - you should use several characters and combine their traps in the most efficient way. Personally speaking, I have found extremely fun and challeging only using one character and its own abilities/traps. And trust me - it is hard, challenging, and sometimes it even seems impossible.When I am playing with my wife - we often spend time discussing where and when to place traps in the latter maps, and we are already working as a well oiled machine in the maps that we know better. We have been able to evolve characters +\- at the same time, and it is nice to see that even though we use different classes, we both feel that our roles as individuals and as a team are important to beat the level. I feel that evolving the characters at a simillar rate has helped improving the fun of the game. If you have a couple of close friends that commit to level their characters at the same pace as you guys, everybody will feel important during game play and everybody will draw the most fun of it.Just a personal opinion, but this is a game I would definitaly recommend, either if you are playing single or multi with close friends.

content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												I've played this for a bit, both single-player and multi.  Beat the campaign, started another char class to do it again, discovered that your solo chars can't be used multiplayer for some reason, started over again, got bored, etc.  It's a fine little action TD game, nothing seriously wrong with it.  I'm just not sure a game like that needs randomized loot drops and crafting and all this other stuff.  There's also a disappointing lack of variety in enemies.  By the time you get a few levels in (and there are a decent number of those), you've pretty much seen everything that's on offer.  The extra classes are good, but I don't think they differentiate from each other enough.  Plus, each one has only a handful of different towers you can make..

												It is a very nice aspect the game has approached with a 3rd person tower defence game: which really stood out to me, I like being able to walk between my defences and see how they interact with each other.I was able to collect loot at my own pace, grinding isn't as much of a bore as some other games and can actually be fun when in a party. Another key aspect of the game is leveling up different statistics of your defences in four different ways: being Map Difficulty,  Character Stats and abilities and gear that you and your party can equip and obviously leveling up the towers themselves. The maps are very well made with barely any bugs that can be abused and the maps all have a couple nice challenge counterparts that give you more of a challenge, variety and better gear. Nice variety of characters to choose from each with their own unique play styles, abilities and specialties and when combined with other classes via coop or just switching out your character mid rounds give you the necessary boost in possibilities.Would definitely recommend to someone new to tower defences and anyone one else really. 8.5/10

content:
Posted: August 4, 2012
												Great Game... Constant New Content...Need Anything Else?Best way I can describe it is that a 3rd person shooter and a tower defense game mixed into one amazing game. You set up defense towers, while you also run around and kill goblins yourself. Each class has their own towers/traps and weapons, a variety team makes the difference. Solo this game is ok, but playing with people online or, better yet, your friends makes this one game I can't stop playing. So much DLC it gets costly to get it all, but it is money well spent on a game like this.Pros:+Game-play+Group play+A lot of new content (now that DD2 is coming out, I expect it to stop adding to this game)+Many characters and missions+Level designs+Can set up a shop to sell equipment and pets+Lots of AchievementsCons:-Solo play-Can get repetitive at times (especially playing solo)-There can be glitches (goblin stuck in wall and mage hiding in door for example, however game will kill them after a couple minutes)So-So:=Graphics (they are good, but not amazing)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												Dungeon defenders has been quite an experience and was one of the first games I really got into. It can be described as a blend of hack and slash loot collection with tower defense, such as the gift from heaven that was Bloons Tower Defense. In terms of how this blend plays out it allows the player to help out the towers during the attck waves meaning a much more immersive experience than other tower defense games. In tradition with games such as diablo there is also a heavy emphasis on randomized loot that can always be improved. This however can lead to some frustrating encounters as loot may drop with better stats, but have a level requirement of 60, at the start of the game. Gameplay plays out very smoothly with the transitions between the building and defending phases, allowing for a breather between the heavy onslaughts, letting you upgrade and repair your defenses as seen fit. The traditional defend the crystal game mode may start to get stale after doing many a mission but thats brings us to my favorite part of the game, the challenges. The challenges of the dungeon defenders are unque mission that put a twist on the workings of the game by changing how fundemental  parts of levels play out. This includes a crystal that teleports around the map, a level in which golbins rain from the sky, one where no towers are allowed, and dozens of others thanks to the large amount of free and paid for content that Dungeon Defenders has recieved post launch. Overall the game is a solid blend of two enjoyable genres that is pleasant romp through many varied environments. I highly reccomend playing with friends as it increases the enjoyment of the game exponentially.The game has taught me that all necromancers are jewish Jay Leno

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												Dungeon Defender is a very nice game it has 4 classes for usual, Apprentice, Squire, Huntress and Monk. Apprentice is a magic man, that uses towers that shoot magical energy and fire while his some defenses are floating magic shields. Squire is a sword type, that uses spiked barricades and Boucers to bouce enemy back from the crystals. Huntress is a stalking spotted leopard that can go invisble to the enemy eye and set down trap like mines that detonate when enemys come in its blast range. Monk is an Aura man that uses Aura to defend the Eternia Crystals, like electric auras tat shock the enemys then they get inside of the aura and helpful auras like his Healing Aurato heal himself and his teammates. You also have a storage that is called your Heros Forge. Items alike armor and weapons are stored in there and you can sell these items from there to gain more money, or Mana, which is also used to build defenses(youll get it once you play it). There are also some funny referances like Light Saber from Star Wars:D. You can color the clothes of your Hero and name your Hero when you properly make them, but while in battle, you can quickly make anoher character with its name and color already done. You can also decorate your own crystal when you first play and you can change it by going to options i think at the main menu. This game is a very good game i really recommend this game and i hope more players play this game there is also a second one it is free right now if you want to play that too(though im not gonna have a summary there most likely xD). And i also recommend that you get the DLC to get even more characters like the summoner that can summon minions that will help you, and fyi they move.Made:6/28/2016 time 1:09        Thank you for reading this summary!!!

content:
Posted: July 26, 2012
 Dungeon Defenders 8.7/10 Unlike Dungeon Defenders 2, Dungeon Defenders is a completly different game. It's the core of what the Dungeon Defenders community enjoys. It had nice DLCs of new unique maps and characters, a challenging difficulty meter and much more. I really enjoyed this game, even when owning high level characters I still can't beat some of the difficulties.Keep in mind DD can get boring without all the DLCs and friends to play with. If you plan on playing solo you can, but when playing with friends it gets even better. The only issues you'll run into is a lack of multiplayer servers, since this is an old game and not much are playing it anymore. Another downfall is in multiplayer, some players have lv 120 characters that can win the maps for you. I don't recomment playing or opening a lobby for high level players to beat the game for you as it's more fun doing it yourself.Overall DD is a great game, try it out.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												This was amazingly fun with a full group of 4 people when I first started it.  Very fun way to handle the tower defense genre.  There is your standard mage with towers, but also interesting ideas like monk with damage/debuff bubbles, archer using traps for support type defense, and a tanky type knight using walls and ballista.  You can increase either your obstacles' effectiveness, your actual hero effectiveness, or a mix of the two.It got too difficult to keep up with much of the harder content without getting some amazing gear, which was only obtainable very briefly via some hardcore exploitation.  By the time we got to that point in the content, there was no legit way to get the gear yourself without trading for exorbitant prices.  Was fun while it lasted, and definitely worth some time just to get through the original/non-DLC part of the game to level up and try it out.  Even more so if you've got a group of buddies.  Have not played in a long time so some of the negative aspects may already be addressed by now, but at this point I'm not likely to return.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2012
												Massively addictive game! This game will likely have you totally absorbed into the fun and strategic world of DD. If you like hack 'n slash, and/or tower defence, then you will absolutely love this game.08/05/2014 EDIT:Dungeon Defenders isn't quite what it used to be, as amazing as it is. What I mean is, the community isn't the same. I'm sure there'll be plenty to disagree, but various times I've tried for games, I've come up with very few. It's a shame, but I suppose all good things must come to an end, at least for me.I have some excellent memories of this game, and even with the online situation being somewhat less than it was, I still absolutely recommend it. The vast trading, all the trophies, enormous amount of gear to collect, the sheer amount of tactics and co-operation, ... there's just too much for me to possibly encapsulate in a few paragraphs of text.I don't play this game anymore, ... I don't really play much of anything anymore, but I do remember--just about--a few things that were negatives about this game:1. The community could sometimes be a bit harsh, but there were also more than enough friendly, helpful players, at least in my experience. Trading could be rough, but it was fun and rewarding, once I figured it all out.2. Unfortunately, there were quite a few hacked items floating around, which was an incredibly disheartening thing for me. I was disgusted when I "got" my very first hacked sword, ... I was completely oblivious, thinking it was just really cool, ... although my Spidey senses were tingling, I guess I just didn't want to believe it, until people happily pointed it out. I dumped the sword and was quite peed off. Still, I didn't find it to be TOO excessive, such as in Torchlight II, in which I just found no sense of achievement, amongst people that are basically God. I like to share my accomplishments and yes, I can be competative, so cheaters with online games like this are a negative for me.3. Performance, even on a powerful rig, was a problem, pretty much down to the game itself, not a hardware thing. Still, the game runs well, the last few times I launched it and tested split-screen on King's Game, something that used to lag like a ♥♥♥♥♥. I'm quite pleased with the performance, nowadays, but I still think it's not very good, I guess I just got used to it. An oversight worth, ... looking over.If it's still anything like I remember, and it's your kind of genre, then definitely get it.NOTE: I'd avoid this game like the plague, if you only have Linux, as it simply doesn't work properly on it. Google "can't collect gems on Dungeon Defenders Linux" or something to that effect, and you'll see why it's basically unplayable.If you have any questions, feel free to ask. It has been a long time, but I still remember bits and pieces.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!This is a Tower defence strategy game.Interface/Menu/SettingsAble to play with your controller.Able to customise the controls on the keyboard.You are able to choose your own screen resolution size.Able to play fullscreen or windowed mode.There is a music volume slidebar available.There is a sound volume slidebar available.There is a mic voice volume slidebar available. including PUSH TO TALK.You can play online or offline. Local or single player.About the game.This is a pretty unique tower defence game. You are able to play with your own hero and build towers. You can focus entirely on a character or only on towers. The heroes are able to level up and they will keep their levels too throughout the game. You are able to upgrade and find weapons/pets to make them stronger. There are many different heroes with their own advantage and disadvantage. But you do have to defend the core. If a core is destroyed, you will lose the game. I do recommend to play online only with your friends. Because sometime there will be a dude messing it up. Or you get kicked instantly or sooner or later from a server.Has a story!Has survival mode.Has alot of difficulty Levels.Able to make a Level scaling lobby.Upgradeable equipment/Towers and pets.Music is extremely good!Alot of different levels/Pets and heroes!Is really addictive.Really great graphics and sceneries.Other things.-------------------I Give this game a 9/10

												I have played this game hours on end enjoying most of my experience with this game. This title (though a few years old now upon writing this) holds up pretty well to various Steam titles and is a must-have staple in your game library. Though the game can be grindy at times, those times will pay off in game progress. With a helpful community for gamers both casual and hardcore, and the creative works that people have made with the Steam Workshop, you will never feel alone as you're bound to find someone on this game. Recommend this to your friends as this game is enjoyed best as a group. Again, a must-have staple for your game library.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												This was amazingly fun with a full group of 4 people when I first started it.  Very fun way to handle the tower defense genre.  There is your standard mage with towers, but also interesting ideas like monk with damage/debuff bubbles, archer using traps for support type defense, and a tanky type knight using walls and ballista.  You can increase either your obstacles' effectiveness, your actual hero effectiveness, or a mix of the two.It got too difficult to keep up with much of the harder content without getting some amazing gear, which was only obtainable very briefly via some hardcore exploitation.  By the time we got to that point in the content, there was no legit way to get the gear yourself without trading for exorbitant prices.  Was fun while it lasted, and definitely worth some time just to get through the original/non-DLC part of the game to level up and try it out.  Even more so if you've got a group of buddies.  Have not played in a long time so some of the negative aspects may already be addressed by now, but at this point I'm not likely to return.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2012
 Dungeon Defenders 8.7/10 Unlike Dungeon Defenders 2, Dungeon Defenders is a completly different game. It's the core of what the Dungeon Defenders community enjoys. It had nice DLCs of new unique maps and characters, a challenging difficulty meter and much more. I really enjoyed this game, even when owning high level characters I still can't beat some of the difficulties.Keep in mind DD can get boring without all the DLCs and friends to play with. If you plan on playing solo you can, but when playing with friends it gets even better. The only issues you'll run into is a lack of multiplayer servers, since this is an old game and not much are playing it anymore. Another downfall is in multiplayer, some players have lv 120 characters that can win the maps for you. I don't recomment playing or opening a lobby for high level players to beat the game for you as it's more fun doing it yourself.Overall DD is a great game, try it out.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												First Bought this game on the PS3 and enjoyed it totally, but found out that the mods were pretty much only on PC so I decided to get a copy on the PC and don't regret it. Picking it up on sale on the humble store is a must to get all the dlc in one package. Now for the gameplay it is a tower defense that can be easy or hard depending on how you make it. Life is always easier with friends, but it doesn't mean you can't play solo easily because the game allows you to switch heroes mid wave and make use of all you heroes towers albeit having separate mana pools.There is one downside I encountered immediately when I started playing though and it was the TrendyNet feature that while cool I didn't choose to start playing multiplayer until I had already created a character locally meaning I had to create an entirely new one. Also you have to be connected to Trendynet to obtain the steam achievements which is a problem too. This is all solved by private games on the Trendynet server though.Despite these little things I do enjoy the game's fantastic design that keeps you in the action at all times trying to support your towers whether through repairs or a carefully placed blast of magic.Overall I do enjoy this game myself and am a fan of the tower defense genre so I recommend it to anyone else who likes them and wants to boost their collection.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												I got bored with Last Stand Mode in Dawn of War 2: Retribution a year ago, this game reminds me a lot of that, but it is quite a bit nicer. Dozens of different maps, many different classes to play (Four come standard, the rest is DLC) and each of them has it's own niche role. Weapons come in many shapes and forms and are fully upgradable.The community here is relatively non-communicative, but even without communication there are some really cool people. Today I started an Apprentice, and after getting him to a basic level in single player, went to do a MP campaign on Hard difficulty. Then suddenly a level 100 Sorcerer named Dumbledore joined the game and carried me through the entire thing. At the end I was level 56. I find it quite amazing that a principal can find the time to run a school, and still help aspiring sorcerers with their levelling.All in all the levelling is not grindy, and the characters are all cool in their own way, except the Jester, who seems to poop out ogres with 100k HP in Easy difficulty games where  it will squash all the sub-level 30 players in it's path since their DPS does not even break a thousand. That said, Shreck is love, Shreck is life.

It's grind heavy at parts and frustratingly difficult/unforgiving at times, but yeah man, I had a great time with this one.It's tower defense in a 3d realm where you can also shoot at or melee mobs!  Bosses!  Humor!  Challenges!  Ahhhh so good.Hitting max level (the first time) is a massive grind but after that you can usually very easily level up and gear additional characters.There's a bit of balance issues between the characters but that's about it.  Great game, very worth it, though I'm not sure how it compares ti DD: eternity yet.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												The greatest and also unique Tower Defense game with the style of a RPG.Your goal is to defend different crystals in different maps and positions from hordes of enemies, using the building and fighting skills of your character, whose powers increases with the experience they gain while defending, and with the equipments you find scattered around the battlefield. In bigger and harder maps, you may consider getting the support of some friends in order to defend every crystal from the evil, and combining your buildings with different stats or different sets will bring your team to the victory.If you're playing alone, you may consider to try out all of the four characters, and to use all of their buildings togheter, in order to succeed in the game;If you're playing with some friends, coordinate each other and combine the different characters's structures in a proper way to have a chance against the wave.If you're going to buy this game now, be aware of one thing: there are lots of DLCs that adds more playable characters, maps, a new difficulty, and the final part of the story of this game. This means that, without buying almost every DLC, you will have only half of the fun from this game, making yourself consider buying the whole Dungeon Defenders Collection.Also, if you're going to play huge maps with some buddies, your friends may experience big lags, even if they have a good computer which can normally handle very huge games, making their match boring and stressful.Though this is a magnificent game, you'll need to shell out a lot of money to really enjoy it; also the developers are no longer working on this game (instead they are in the sequel of this, a MOBA genre), so the lag problems and such won't be fixed.Buy it at your own risk.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												If you're playing single player, you might not enjoy this that much. If, however, you're playing with a friend (or three), especially if you're playing locally, then you'll likely have a lot of fun.It's a tower defense game with RPG levelling elements and randomly generated loot galore.  The regular campaign is interesting, and the eternia shards campaign extends the challenge and the difficulty a great deal, but it introduce new enemies which have some... balance issues.  The game can get a bit grindy at points while you try to acquire new loot, and some of the extended/additional levels really don't seem that well thought out, but there is still a lot of fun to be had with this game.If a tower defense with RPG elements piques your interested, then I'd just go the whole hog and get the full collection - it's definitely worth your money (especially if it's on sale). There is the potentially for many, many hours of gameplay here, provided you're interested in the style and the strategy. The only warning I would give is that it's much less fun single player, and the online multiplayer community is fairly limited at this point in time.  If you need to play online for your multiplayer, I'd probably just wait until Dungeon Defenders 2 comes out and see how that's received.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												Dungeon Defenders adds a new twist to tower defense with a mishmash of RPG, action, and tower defense gameplay elements making for a worthwhile investment. There is plenty of content to keep players busy – whether it be working their way through the campaign and tackling challenges. It’s not with its setbacks, though, with the less-than-exciting combat system and loot that feels more like a chore than a reward system.Tower defense sits at the heart of Dungeon Defenders. The player takes on the role of a Squire, Apprentice, Huntress, or Monk using traps, barricades and magic to defend the castle from an army of evil creatures these would-be child heroes have mistakenly unleashed. Each level plays out in an arena with several entry points for enemies to spawn from. It is the player’s job to analyze the level map and exploit choke points with barricades and traps to prevent enemies from destroying the Eternia crystal at the center of the map. The game is played from the third-person perspective, requiring characters to traverse the map to set up towers while battling enemies along the way.Enemies are varied and numerous, requiring different strategies to counter their abilities. Hulking orcs will devastate defenses, mages heal enemy units, and suicidal kobolds rush towers with dynamite strapped to their backs. Minibosses in the form of giant ogres made us rethink our tower placement in several situations and the major bosses present the biggest challenges in the game.Dungeon Defenders has all of the workings of the standard RPG fused into the tower defense gameplay. Player classes have unique abilities, armor, weapon types, and towers. Killing enemies, conquering campaign levels, and completing challenges earns experience which unlocks abilities and towers as well as more powerful items. Character and tower attributes can be upgraded with points earned upon leveling through a somewhat confusing menu system – improving maximum health, damage, casting speed, and movement speed, among others.All of these features add a great deal of replayability to the game – as does the multiplayer. Once we worked through the levels and beefed up one character, we wanted to level up a complementary character to make proper use of the character swap feature and get the upper hand on some of the more difficult challenges. Setting up spiked barricades as the Squire and switching to the Apprentice to place projectile throwing magic towers makes for a devastating combination. It feels great to level up a character, unlock the advanced towers, and add them to your defense strategy. Playing with a friend or three adds a new dimension in strategy as we were required to actively communicate in tower placement, mana distribution, and repair efforts to hold back the onslaught. The real fun comes in joining a party of friends to tackle the hardest challenges and picking up epic loot.Unfortunately the action aspect of gameplay falls short. The combat became stale very quickly. Although the characters have special abilities like the Squire’s spin attack or the Huntress’ invisibility, we rarely found a need to use them. Enemies were easily dispatched with well-placed towers and planning trap layouts and developing strategies was fun, but jumping into the fray was not – especially with the melee characters. Combat essentially involves mashing on the one attack button and maybe throwing in a special ability for kicks. Neither feels particularly effective and leaves the combat feeling shallow.Another problem we had with Dungeon Defenders was the loot. Items can be found in treasure chests and is also dropped by enemies. Picking up epic new armor or weapons and equipping them to benefit from their attribute bonuses is a strong motivator to up the difficulty on the challenges, but the problem lies in having to sort through piles and piles of useless loot at the end of a wave. Checking each dropped item’s stats to compare to our equipped set slowed the game down considerably since all of the loot is spread across the map and it takes at least a few seconds to inspect an item. While we could just run through the map and throw everything into our item box to review later, having fewer, more useful drops would have kept loot gathering from becoming such a chore.Dungeon Defenders is a worthwhile addition to your game library with plenty of content for the price. Although the combat falls short, the tower defense gameplay, RPG elements, and the challenging game modes will have fans of tower defense delighted.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												Got this game cheap during the Halloween sale and I couldn't be happier with it.  I was looking for a game to play with my two kids under 10 and this has been perfect for us to play together.I've been impressed with how much it has kept my attention, I thought this would just be a mindless button masher.  But between all of the characters (we bought them all), the massive amount of loot and the strategy of the tower placement, we have not been bored yet in close to 8 hours of play.  And better yet - we've only scratched the surface.So to those looking for a game to play with the family - I'd give this a definite thumbs up.  My kids struggled a bit to grasp some of the concepts in the beginning but once they figured out the strategy of placing the towers and how to evaluate whether the loot was better than what they already had, it was easy.  It's been really fun working together.Quick note for anyone else interested - I am using the mouse/keyboard and my kids are using xbox controllers - definitely working out well.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												Dungeon Defenders adds a new twist to tower defense with a mishmash of RPG, action, and tower defense gameplay elements making for a worthwhile investment. There is plenty of content to keep players busy – whether it be working their way through the campaign and tackling challenges. It’s not with its setbacks, though, with the less-than-exciting combat system and loot that feels more like a chore than a reward system.Tower defense sits at the heart of Dungeon Defenders. The player takes on the role of a Squire, Apprentice, Huntress, or Monk using traps, barricades and magic to defend the castle from an army of evil creatures these would-be child heroes have mistakenly unleashed. Each level plays out in an arena with several entry points for enemies to spawn from. It is the player’s job to analyze the level map and exploit choke points with barricades and traps to prevent enemies from destroying the Eternia crystal at the center of the map. The game is played from the third-person perspective, requiring characters to traverse the map to set up towers while battling enemies along the way.Enemies are varied and numerous, requiring different strategies to counter their abilities. Hulking orcs will devastate defenses, mages heal enemy units, and suicidal kobolds rush towers with dynamite strapped to their backs. Minibosses in the form of giant ogres made us rethink our tower placement in several situations and the major bosses present the biggest challenges in the game.Dungeon Defenders has all of the workings of the standard RPG fused into the tower defense gameplay. Player classes have unique abilities, armor, weapon types, and towers. Killing enemies, conquering campaign levels, and completing challenges earns experience which unlocks abilities and towers as well as more powerful items. Character and tower attributes can be upgraded with points earned upon leveling through a somewhat confusing menu system – improving maximum health, damage, casting speed, and movement speed, among others.All of these features add a great deal of replayability to the game – as does the multiplayer. Once we worked through the levels and beefed up one character, we wanted to level up a complementary character to make proper use of the character swap feature and get the upper hand on some of the more difficult challenges. Setting up spiked barricades as the Squire and switching to the Apprentice to place projectile throwing magic towers makes for a devastating combination. It feels great to level up a character, unlock the advanced towers, and add them to your defense strategy. Playing with a friend or three adds a new dimension in strategy as we were required to actively communicate in tower placement, mana distribution, and repair efforts to hold back the onslaught. The real fun comes in joining a party of friends to tackle the hardest challenges and picking up epic loot.Unfortunately the action aspect of gameplay falls short. The combat became stale very quickly. Although the characters have special abilities like the Squire’s spin attack or the Huntress’ invisibility, we rarely found a need to use them. Enemies were easily dispatched with well-placed towers and planning trap layouts and developing strategies was fun, but jumping into the fray was not – especially with the melee characters. Combat essentially involves mashing on the one attack button and maybe throwing in a special ability for kicks. Neither feels particularly effective and leaves the combat feeling shallow.Another problem we had with Dungeon Defenders was the loot. Items can be found in treasure chests and is also dropped by enemies. Picking up epic new armor or weapons and equipping them to benefit from their attribute bonuses is a strong motivator to up the difficulty on the challenges, but the problem lies in having to sort through piles and piles of useless loot at the end of a wave. Checking each dropped item’s stats to compare to our equipped set slowed the game down considerably since all of the loot is spread across the map and it takes at least a few seconds to inspect an item. While we could just run through the map and throw everything into our item box to review later, having fewer, more useful drops would have kept loot gathering from becoming such a chore.Dungeon Defenders is a worthwhile addition to your game library with plenty of content for the price. Although the combat falls short, the tower defense gameplay, RPG elements, and the challenging game modes will have fans of tower defense delighted.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												Got this game cheap during the Halloween sale and I couldn't be happier with it.  I was looking for a game to play with my two kids under 10 and this has been perfect for us to play together.I've been impressed with how much it has kept my attention, I thought this would just be a mindless button masher.  But between all of the characters (we bought them all), the massive amount of loot and the strategy of the tower placement, we have not been bored yet in close to 8 hours of play.  And better yet - we've only scratched the surface.So to those looking for a game to play with the family - I'd give this a definite thumbs up.  My kids struggled a bit to grasp some of the concepts in the beginning but once they figured out the strategy of placing the towers and how to evaluate whether the loot was better than what they already had, it was easy.  It's been really fun working together.Quick note for anyone else interested - I am using the mouse/keyboard and my kids are using xbox controllers - definitely working out well.

												Fun game, enjoyable with 2+ people!Very good art style and if you're a fan of tower defense games such as Orcs must Die then this game is a must!Eye feasting glourious battles with friends, combine 4 heros of your choice and fight through various levels - All the way at the bottom of a glorious castle, to the top!Very good grind factor, and excellent replay value! This game features many DLC's all of which are frequently on sale during summer and various other events, so if you're keen on getting a few new classes or even the Eternia Shards DLC, keep an eye out!If you enjoy strategically planning and placing towers at your own will, and grinding various hours to have the best equipement look no more! Great game, 10/10 proud owner for 3 years!

Posted: July 13, 2012
												At first I thought this game was going to be ho hum, yet another tower defense/FPS in an ever-growing genre.  I had already picked up Sanctum and Orcs Must Die and thought, why would I want this?  So I passed initially.  I wish I hadn't.  This game is actually very engrossing.  Sure, gear is of great importance, esp. in Endgame, but there is quite a bit of strategy involved.  Plus, the community is great, so you also get to have a lot of fun.  Highly recommended.Make sure you also buy Shards Complete DLC, which is *the* Endgame.  Enjoy!

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												This game is amazing it's like someone took the best part of Tower Defense from Warcraft and slapped it into Diablo II. You can build cool towers then sit back and drink a coke or you can play a combat focused class and be in the middle of the fray. The learning curve takes a bit to figure out on multi-player games and you might get yelled at once or twice for picking up something you can't use but overall it's a pretty easy game to get good at and a pain to be great. Most of the players are pretty laid back and cool, many times someone jumps in to give me advise randomly. I would also suggest you don't play this game alone. Friends, even random players, make this game more fun by a factor of 10. Not to mention you can see strats in play and how the other classes operate. I would say go for the Collection pack if you can the extra classes and maps are very cool and change the game play a little. If not you might get Jelly early watching others playing them. I put in about 40 hours since I got the game and I haven't even scratched the surface. Get in on a 75% off sale and you won't be disappointed.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												4-player Co-op Tower Defense/ARPG hybrid with a sort of Diablo style random loot system.  Fun to play solo, even more fun with friends.  There are a lot of different challenge modes, difficulty settings, maps and even some PvP modes like CTF and such. number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												One of the best examples of "indie" gaming in recent years. A real joy to sink many, many hours into.It hybrids straight up Tower Defence with 3rd person battling so very well that it's without peer. A lovely clean art style which is well presented so that it remains easy on the eye even during periods of intense action and after hours of play. Fighting is very fluid indeed, and where it also shines is in the variety of character classes and their applicable skills.The Mage for example, has the most conventional options in straight-up towers that fire missiles. Monks and Archer have some clever traps and AOE placings. Played on their own they really demand different layouts and tactics, but when played together (you can place traps/towers with one character and switch and combine them on the fly) they REALLY sing.This lends itself to some very good multiplayer play.Content-wise, the main campaign is solid, and will last you a good few hours on the first playthrough. However, with various difficulty settings (and the appropriate loot to go with them) it begs repeated play. You're unlikely to get bored with these basic levels, as they are very well designed, and will offer the freedom for a variety of experimentation in layouts.But, if this were not enough, there's also a myriad of challenges based on these maps which will truly test your abilities - with their own unique rewards too!So, add in Steam Workshop ability which has been well-supported by the community, and you have one of the best bang-for-your-buck games on Steam.If you love Tower Defence, or even are remotely interested in the genre, then this is an essential purchase.

number of helpful: 8 of 15 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												Dungeon Defenders is a quirky little game where, on top of being a tower defense, you also have to run around and shoot things. Ever played Sanctum 1 or 2? Then keep your money, bud, cause this is just a less fun version.The basic premise is you four heroes in training must hold the line against invading waves of heroes while the real heroes are out gettin donuts or somethin. I didn't pay attention to that bit. So you build turrets and collect resources dropped from chests and enemies to build turrets or to upgrade your abilities and weapons. In the end we have an tower defense third person shooter with rpg elements. It's got a cute little cell shaded graphic style that I can't help but find appealing and honestly the actual mechanics of it all aren't half bad if you can excuse the fact that projectile attacks are virtually useless if not awkward as a 14 year old trying to talk about his sexual experiences in a positive light. Yeah I bet you got it good last night, Uncle Paul.So why not reccomend it? BECAUSE IT'S BOOOOOOOOORING. Honestly, the game is so unbelievably slow paced. Everything is slow, the enemies are slow, the projectiles are slow, the turrets are slow, every attack is slow and boring and lame. I'd call it a childrens game, but Kameo: Elements of Power was a childrens game and on the hardest difficulty can at least keep you paying attention. You know what else is a childrens game? The Legend of Zelda. A game that isn't combat orriented still has far superior combat mechanics and faster paced gameplay then a game that boasts it. On top of the slow game play, it's just plain awkward. Projectile attacks can hardly be called skill shots, since the move barely any faster than the enemies and you never run out of amunition. Only the mage and the knight are really worth anything because the knight can literally just stop an entire wave with two turrets and shell them with cannonballs that are basically 2 hit kills on large enemies. The monk supposedly has healing abilities but there's never any need because you have to actually try to die in this game. Simply put, it's boring. It's cute, it's quirky, it's unique(kinda), but it's just too slow. It's upgrade system is just a massive min/maxfest and leaves so much to be desired.Should you buy it?Do you play EVE online? Yes? This game is gonna be too slow even for you.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												This game is the sole purpose of my life.  The dungeons are like pure oceans of beauty that touch my soul and caress my thighs (metaphorically). As I plunge into them, they envelop my body and stimulate my galloping abs. With every keystroke my heart beats faster, and my spine tingles from the endless adventure and heartwrenching story.  I had never cried in my life, but this game touched me in ways that can never be undone. No one was there to wipe the tears flowing from my glimmering eyes, but when I looked into the mages eyes I felt safe again.  The heat of his passion dried my tears and warmed my fragile heart.  Never again will I feel lonely, alone in my bedroom with no escape.  As I defended dungeons, I realized my reason for living in this dangerous world.  I have transcended the human world, and am now living with a purpose. The dungeons. They call for me.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												Dungeon Defenders is one of the laziest horde defense games I've ever played. After downloading the game you are immediatly swarmed with adverts for their dlc and offers. This is really annoying because it gets in the way of the gameplay and slows everything down to a snails pace. There is virtually no tutorial to speak of; you need to figure out how to play the game on your own. You have 4 starting classes to choose from (unless you shelled out the extra cash to buy more characters). The classes themselves are actually somewhat unique, but it becomes quickly apparent that there are two classes that outshine the others. The graphics are ugly, bright, and basic. My eyes were sore after playing for a few hours. The items that the game occasionally spits at you don't feel unique or interesting at all. The gameplay revolves around collecting gems, putting up towers, and occasionally chopping down bigger monsters. The only part about this game I enjoyed was playing with my friends. The game is dull, unbalanced, and sluggish. Don't buy this.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
												Summary: Orcs Must Die with experience and loot.Multiplayer: up to 8Completion: 20 hrsCards: NoCloud: No (but has online-mode saves)Dungeon Defenders plays out much like Orcs Must Die, where you attack waves of enemies emerging from several entrances by using towers, traps, minions, or just plain weapons. The game supports up to quite a few players, though four players is a safe bet for most maps.There's a lot to like about the game. It has a fairly good progression, as level-ups and items felt like large improvements in the early game. As you head towards the endgame though, item upgrades become much less frequent, and you may struggle on a number of later hardcore maps. Notably... there's a distinct lack of a proper tutorial. It does not teach you things like what your health bar and mana bar is. It does not teach you how to equip things. It does not teach you about sets. It does not teach you about upgrading items.Interestingly, the game allows you to switch heroes on the fly between rounds. Thus you can benefit from defenses another character you have, and then switch back to the one you want to level. It's an interesting idea, as it greatly simplifies the need for grinding, but at the same time, the early charm is entirely lost because you are packing high-powered defenses on a low level character and can just afk to victory with minimal strategy. Shrug. It's hard to say if the benefits outweigh the downsides.Each map allots you and your party a shared Defense Unit (DU) pool with which to summon  your defenses. I kind of wish there was a slight change to DU. I'd like it so that every character had a minimum DU devoted to themselves, and the rest would be a shared DU. That way all players would have at least some use for tower stats. Tower placement can get a but clumsy, since you can only summon within a short radius of your position. If the tower is too close to certain things, then you can't place it. All too often I find myself needing to cancel, reposition, and try to summon again, which can be problematic in combat when mobs may be attacking you. Unlike OMD there is no means to shape your enemy paths, but you can place structures that enemies will attack.The game likes to throw loot at you. A lot of it. You'll be seeing items left and right, polluting the entire field, and you won't know what to grab. Fortunately the game includes a rudimentary system that puts an indicator on items it thinks may be an upgrade for you, however more often than not the indicator is completely wrong. All the items you loot go to your item bank, which unfortunately is very poorly managed. You can create your own folders, but doing so shrinks your items visible per page. I would have really liked a way to sort and reorder items myself. At this point I would settle for nothing but a columns of text instead of the gigantic 12 icons at a time.This game offers one very nice feature most other games in this genre do not - the ability to change camera angles. By zooming in and out with the mouse wheel you can go seamlessly into first person, over-the-shoulder, and overhead views. I can't tell how much I wanted a feature like this in other games! There's even a 4th sort of view if you play as the Summoner, who can enter an RTS-like mode, which is even better. One handy touch is that if you die, especially in hardcore, you are allowed to free-roam the map while dead. It's nice to see the outside environment and to scout for other party members while in this mode.Dungeon Defenders offers five difficulties per map. You can probably ignore the first few, as those are almost always too easy. However, the game could probably use another difficulty between insane and nightmare. There is a sudden spike when you hit nightmare as you fight enemies with considerably more health, and the ability to air drop from anywhere. I had a lot of fun playing through the maps with some friends when the maps would just barely kick our butt, typically beating us on the last wave. Eventually we got our act together and can blow through almost everything, but the process of discovery was great. With the exception of one map, the game seems to run pretty well in multiplayer with minimal lag, so thumbs up for that!I am impressed at the variety of play modes the game offers. It goes well beyond the standard tower defense, including modes such as PvP, run a gauntlet, escort the crystal, and more. I much enjoyed the journey to reach high levels. It's a shame I can't really experience that again. It's a great multiplayer experience, I'll grant it that. I give Dungeon Defenders a 8.5/10, mainly knocking points for the Item Bank that is incredibly tedious to sift through. If you like tower defense + shooters, this game will serve you well.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												Basically, the developers tried to chart in very-well-charted areas but ended up charting them all on the same chart. Tower defense, hack'n'slash, "RPG" elements, it's definitely all there. The big question is: does it work? To sum it up, my answer is "not quite". Dungeon Defenders works on the base premise that there's something that must be left untouched by the vile horde of monsters in a fantasy setting for its core gameplay. And as advertised, you can pick any of the hero classes and have multiple heroes with persisting stats the longer you play the game, swapping them out as needed. Each hero has multiple stats, the "RPG" elements now, that make it more proficient in their respective stats' areas. Care to improve your tower damage? Stat it up on gaining a level. Maybe you want to make your hero beefier? Same deal. Move speed, hero's damage, cast time improvements? It's all there. There's even equipment for the heroes to use and pets that function as "stat sticks" if nothing else; arguably the most important piece of equipment are weapons.Each level works in waves, which is a good thing. Since every wave is always the same, unless in certain cases, you can memorize how waves play out and plan how to place your defenses. Simple enough; just do what works for you, some would say.But here's where it gets messy: defense points, used to place defenses, ARE SHARED BETWEEN PLAYERS. What does that mean? It means that someone that specialized in tower-gameplay stats will be prefered for building rather than a hybrid or an "action-hero"-built someone. And this is where the game simply is broken; they encourage this sort of behaviour further with insane higher difficulty modes, where everyone has to be just perfect to win. If you're out with your tower builder you gain experience with him, and vice-versa with your action guy. Playing alone, then, is frustrating because if you're switching around you're not really efficient either.It also doesn't feel rewarding to be a good tower-builder, because if you're online someone else will just be using their left mouse button to mash the hordes down in between doing their best to avoid your towers' innevitable demise. It feels rewarding to be that button masher, but not the strategist that should-but-isn't able to defeat the insane difficulty level's horde; that's my biff with this game.Yes, it's fun at first. But unless you're playing in the "unregulated" league you're only going to reach the beggining of the end-game without a good group online, and playing in the unregulated league is where all the hackage and cheat-enabled characters are, which make the game pointless anyway. My final recomendation? Play the game, but be prepared to think it was all a waste of time.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												I'm conflicted. The base game w/ the DLC that came before the Eternia Shards Campaign is a total gem of a Co-op Tower Defense game that is totally worth your time and money.Unfortunately, the same cannot be said for what came after, as the game has over time been slowly transformed into a totally infuriating grindfest, plagued by poor decisions from the devs. Getting decent gear becomes a nightmare later on, due to negative stat rolls everywhere, random upgrade values and the vast quantities of garbage that drops.Nightmare difficuly was a tacked-on, unbalanced mess that made entire strategies null and void.  Character classes became either totally mandatory (Summoner/EV) or totally useless.However, I still recommend the base game to anyone who loves TD.  Hell, if you like endless grinding, I guess the DLC will float your boat too - just don't say I didn't warn you.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
												Great game, horrid administration by the company. I was vac banned (along with several hundred other people) from this game's servers a few months after release after using an autoclicker (the game's basic attack requires spamming your clicker) advertised for use by a Moderator on their Official Forums. Soon after the bans went out and rage started spewing in on that post the moderater account magically disappeared and trendy had no idea what the angry threads were about. Unfortunately due to lack of publicity and unsympathetic assumptions on those banned this issue was never properly resolved.TL;DR - Good game, Beware the company that can't own up to their mistakes and ratify them after wrongfully banning users via VAC.

Posted: September 17, 2014
												Have you played orcs must die before? have you? ok this game is no where like it.1) the graphics , textures , artwork is fairly pleasing.2) game play is way too smooth , controls are easy and simple.3) incase you didn't know its a tower defence game , so the ''action'' isn't going beyond building some towers and watching them.4) well , you can also buy gears , combine and upgrade your weapon/equipments , enhancing them , adding abilities and etc , and you can also buy pets , super rare ones , with weekly refreshed shop (you can use ingame currency)5) also this game was atempting to make a mmo community inside it , but i guess they faild duo to several reasons and they are: a) the servers are ...... <- you can insert any bad word here , because simply theres missions you can't pass alone , so you need company , and when u ask for one , the ingame servers may not be dead but , can't support to connect people from different countries.b) the game itself is at a point is so repeatitive and rather boring , which will make u eventually get bored even if you play with friends.c) you may spend lots of time just to grind for decent equipments and then find out that your level has grown during that , that you wont be needing this equipments anymore ( you will need new ones ).-This game is nice , but i dont recommend you to buy it at full price , and i dont recommend you to have it at all if you don't like that type of game genre either.  6/10.

												On first sight, you may think this game is for kids.Well, it is.. but behind all this realy for young people looking graphics there is a genius game.I would say its the most interactive TD (Tower Defense) Game i have seen so far.+++ Coop online and / SPLITSCREEN !++ Many stages (actually infinite because of the workshop) ++ Class system - You may start as knight or Mage or whatever++ 3D (awesome for a TD game already)++ Its not just building Towers / You can actually "be" the tower (classes which dont use towers) or just create a bubble that slows enemys ( monk )++ Many Items ( Little helpers, armor or guns / all custom upgradable [Maybe you got gloves that give the player HP or Tower HP and you dont want Tower HP, you will just upgrade the players HP])++ Lovely money system-/+ If you play on that no cheat servers (which do not support custom maps), you will have to pay alot for map packs. NOTE: These packs contain some realy awesome maps! Some packs give you maps where you have to destroy the towers and achieve something.-- Can be boring as you arrive on the top level-- Kid graphics-- custom maps may lead to cheat weapons that you can just earn on themI hope that helped you guys out. For me, it was a nice game by the time I played it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
												By the definition of MOBA (Multiplayer Online Battle Arena), Dungeon Defenders is one. Dungeon Defenders took this one step further, and added in Tower Defense to the mix. Makes for a nice variation of available playstyles, ranging from tactical tower placement, to full-on onslaught physical offense. Enjoyable little chibi-style characters give the game an entertaining environment. The audio tracks are very atmospheric for what's going on in-game, and most of the levels offer enough variety from one to the other to keep the game entertaining for playthrough one. However, after the initial playthrough, the game gets incredibly grindy. Having beaten most of the game on medium or hard difficulty on my first run, I ended at nearly level 50, but most of the post-game content (almost) requires levels into the seventies. Very entertaining game to grab a few friends and use for a LAN party or general multiplayer shenanigans, but can quickly become a grind-fest for any single-player fans out there.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2015
												With Dungeon Defenders 2 in Early Access, I'm not sure how many people are going to want to buy this game now but I gave myself a personal mission to review all the games in my library and that includes this one.I'll tip my hat and keep it as brief as possible.I recommend this game, this was my introduction to Tower Defense and it was lot of fun. I did not appreciate the fact that my Adept was mandatory at all times to solo things, since his defenses were the only ones I found strong enough to withstand the monster waves if I swapped to another character.The base game without spending alot in extra DLC doesn't offer a whole lot of levels or variety to keep things fresh. You'll cruise through those levels and then I found myself grinding the same level over and over for mana to buy gear because I sure wasn't going to see anything useful ever drop and I don't know how viable buying gear from other players is anymore.I know, I mostly listed negatives but this game WAS fun and WAS enjoyable. It's a great idea at it's core, it just didn't offer enough content even with the DLC (since most of those levels aren't worth farming for any reason), to keep my interest for terribly long. That said, I still burned tons of hours on this game. You can see that I believe.Dungeon Defenders 1 is a good game and it's fun to play but with the sequel in Early Access, I can only hope they see all the shortcomings they had with this game do a much better job with the sequel. This was a great idea, and I hope they build on it and make the sequel into what this game could have been.Don't pay alot for this if you're interested. You won't find it entertaing for long, but for as long as you do play it, you'll have fun with it. It was a really neat game that in spite of alot of fumbles in it's design direction, came out a blast to sink alot of hours into.

												You need to play Dungeon Defenders with other people. Sure, you could struggle alone and fail repeatedly across the many levels and risk missing the core of the game, but if you gather some friends for local co-op, or even go online with random strangers, you'll find countless hours of entrancingly addictive gameplay as it was intended to be enjoyed. So basically, if you have friends to play with..get the game. If not, don't bother (unless you enjoy playing with strangers).

Posted: April 17, 2015
												By the definition of MOBA (Multiplayer Online Battle Arena), Dungeon Defenders is one. Dungeon Defenders took this one step further, and added in Tower Defense to the mix. Makes for a nice variation of available playstyles, ranging from tactical tower placement, to full-on onslaught physical offense. Enjoyable little chibi-style characters give the game an entertaining environment. The audio tracks are very atmospheric for what's going on in-game, and most of the levels offer enough variety from one to the other to keep the game entertaining for playthrough one. However, after the initial playthrough, the game gets incredibly grindy. Having beaten most of the game on medium or hard difficulty on my first run, I ended at nearly level 50, but most of the post-game content (almost) requires levels into the seventies. Very entertaining game to grab a few friends and use for a LAN party or general multiplayer shenanigans, but can quickly become a grind-fest for any single-player fans out there.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												Dungeon Defenders is a LOT of fun. It's extremely addicting, so be wary if you don't have a lot of time to sit down and play at any given moment (or set an alarm to stop) because you will play wave after wave after wave. With all of the DLC campaigns that you can purchase (cheap, especially during the Steam Sales), Dungeon Defenders has plenty of content to keep anybody busy for a really long time. There are several characters to choose from, although (exempting the original four) they are all DLC. Easy to learn, difficult to master, Dungeon Defenders offers content for any age at any level!

Posted: November 18, 2014
												A tower defense game where you are a child and must defend crystals that your parents left at your castle as they left to go on some sort of trip. Although some people criticize the graphics of this game, the overall gameplay is pretty decent and entertaining if you play with friends online. There are a variety of classes to choose from (if you buy more from the add-ons) and the game can get pretty intense pretty fast. I enjoyed playing the game on the Playstation, so I bought the game on sale and it was worth the price. Entertaining, difficult, cartoony, and I enjoyed the sound track. 7.8/10

content:
Posted: May 6, 2012
												This game will take part of your life and turn it into good memories. It has nice graphics, balanced class system (eventho it might not look like it for first first ~50hours in), quite okay storyline and the best, great loot system!I really recommend it for persons who like to grind and get better gear and challenge from higher difficulties, which is really rewarding.End-game becomes really, really hard at one point, but that's only about 150+ hours in. This game is totally worth playing and buying all the DLC's (which are by the way pretty viable for the experience and are also cheap), because it's fun alone and even more fun with friends!There's also a pvp-mode but that's nothing special in my opinion.If you buy this game, play on ranked mode, because there's no reason not to and prepare yourself to spend hours and hours on map called Magus Quarters!

												On first sight, you may think this game is for kids.Well, it is.. but behind all this realy for young people looking graphics there is a genius game.I would say its the most interactive TD (Tower Defense) Game i have seen so far.+++ Coop online and / SPLITSCREEN !++ Many stages (actually infinite because of the workshop) ++ Class system - You may start as knight or Mage or whatever++ 3D (awesome for a TD game already)++ Its not just building Towers / You can actually "be" the tower (classes which dont use towers) or just create a bubble that slows enemys ( monk )++ Many Items ( Little helpers, armor or guns / all custom upgradable [Maybe you got gloves that give the player HP or Tower HP and you dont want Tower HP, you will just upgrade the players HP])++ Lovely money system-/+ If you play on that no cheat servers (which do not support custom maps), you will have to pay alot for map packs. NOTE: These packs contain some realy awesome maps! Some packs give you maps where you have to destroy the towers and achieve something.-- Can be boring as you arrive on the top level-- Kid graphics-- custom maps may lead to cheat weapons that you can just earn on themI hope that helped you guys out. For me, it was a nice game by the time I played it.

Like all tower defences but the actual First & third person view with multiple Heros and weapons to choose from.
